ACMD501.name: ACMD 501: Introduction to Academic Medicine Worldwide (3.0 units)
ACMD501.desc: Introduces the masters program; includes historical development of training in the health professions; current issues, challenges and opportunities in academic medicine and health worldwide.

ACMD502.name: ACMD 502: Becoming a Leader in Academic Medicine Worldwide (3.0 units)
ACMD502.desc: Current approaches to leadership within the context of global academic medicine and health professions education; individual applications, group dynamics, teamwork, and interpersonal skill enhancement.

ACMD512.name: ACMD 512: Competencies in Academic Medicine and Health II (3.0 units)
ACMD512.desc: Learning theory, teaching methods, assessment techniques related to acquisition and reinforcement of competencies related to parient care, practice-based learning and improvement and systems-based practice.

ACMD513.name: ACMD 513: Professionalism in Academic Medicine and Health (3.0 units)
ACMD513.desc: Acquisition and evaluation of interpersonal and communication skills and professionalism including ethics and cultural competence; within the context of health care disparities and health initiatives.

ACMD591.name: ACMD 591: Designing Research on Innovations in Academic Medicine (2.0 units)
ACMD591.desc: Introduction to design and scholarly review of innovations in health professions education; needs assessment, problem selection, use of research methods to study an innovation.

ACMD598.name: ACMD 598: Fieldwork: Designing Innovations for the Health Professions (1.0-3.0 units, max 3)
ACMD598.desc: Individual projects designing curricular or other innovations for the home program as an application of Year 1 concepts and as part of the capstone experience. Graded CR/NC.

ACMD621.name: ACMD 621: Capstone Portfolio for the Master of Academic Medicine (1.0 unit)
ACMD621.desc: Role of portfolios for teachers and learners; develop a personal capstone portfolio that represents each learners accomplishment of the core competencies of the MACM program.

ANST505.name: ANST 505: Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I (2.0 units)
ANST505.desc: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency. Prerequisites: ANST 501 and ANST 502. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

ANST507.name: ANST 507: Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II (2.0 units)
ANST507.desc: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency. Prerequisites: ANST 503, ANST 504 and ANST 505. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

ANST508.name: ANST 508: Research: Investigative Inquiry (3.0 units)
ANST508.desc: Utilization of research, which includes the evaluation of research, problem identification within the practice setting, awareness of practice outcomes and the clinical application of research. Recommended preparation: research course; basic statistics.

ANST509.name: ANST 509: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I (2.0 units)
ANST509.desc: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to geriatric, obstetrical, and pediatric anesthesia; anesthetic management to include medically compromised patients. Prerequisite: ANST 505, ANST 506, ANST 507. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

ANST511.name: ANST 511: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II (2.0 units)
ANST511.desc: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to neuroanesthesia, cardiac anesthesia, trauma anesthesia, critical care and pain management. Prerequisite: ANST 509. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

ANST512.name: ANST 512: Research Integration: Capstone Experience (2.0 units)
ANST512.desc: A capstone course that requires student to demonstrate ability to integrate theory, research, and practice through a mentored research experience with direct relevance to graduate specialization. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

ANST513.name: ANST 513: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia III (2.0 units)
ANST513.desc: Correlation of advanced techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in diverse specialty anesthesia rotations. Prerequisite: ANST 505, ANST 507, ANST 509, ANST 511. Open only to Nurse Anesthesiology majors.

ANST590.name: ANST 590: Directed Research (1.0-12.0 units)
ANST590.desc: Research leading to the master's degree in nurse anesthesia. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open to nurse anesthesia majors only. Graded CR/NC.

ANST591.name: ANST 591: Special Projects (1.0-4.0 units, max 4)
ANST591.desc: Supervised learning in functional and/or clinical area of focus reflecting current trends and development in the field of nurse anesthesia. Open to nurse anesthesia majors only. Graded CR/NC.

ANST603.name: ANST 603: Anatomy and Advanced Health Assessment (4.0 units)
ANST603.desc: Lectures and laboratory simulation in anatomy emphasizing structure and function of major organs to include brain, cardiovascular, lungs, liver, kidneys and musculoskeletal systems. Acceptance into the USC Program of Nurse Anesthesia.

ANST604.name: ANST 604: Healthcare Policy for Advocacy in Health Care (3.0 units)
ANST604.desc: Examining the health care system focusing on policy development, health care costs, quality and patient safety, access to care, disparities, and future trends.

ANST610.name: ANST 610: Advanced Physiology for Nurse Anesthesia Practice (4.0 units)
ANST610.desc: An investigation of the human cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, hepatic, neurological, and hematological systems and cellular physiology with special emphasis on how these systems relate to anesthesia management.

ANST611.name: ANST 611: Leadership and Collaborative Practice (3.0 units)
ANST611.desc: Emphasis on the professional components of nurse anesthesia practice including scope of practice, organizational leadership, accountability, ethics and collaborative practice.

ANST614.name: ANST 614: Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I (2.0 units)
ANST614.desc: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency.

ANST615.name: ANST 615: Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II (2.0 units)
ANST615.desc: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency.

ANST618.name: ANST 618: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia III (2.0 units)
ANST618.desc: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to neuroanesthesia, cardiac anesthesia, trauma anesthesia, critical care and pain management.

ANST620A.name: ANST 620a: Clinical Synthesis I (1.0 unit)
ANST620A.desc: A two semester curriculum promoting synthesis and mastery of topics integral to the art and science of nurse anesthesia planning, management, and delivery.

ANST621B.name: ANST 621b: Clinical Synthesis II (1.0 unit)
ANST621B.desc: A two semester curriculum promoting synthesis and mastery of topics integral to nurse anesthesia planning, management, and delivery. A continuation of ANST 620.

ANST694A.name: ANST 694a: Doctoral Capstone Project (1.0 unit)
ANST694A.desc: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate. The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

ANST694B.name: ANST 694b: Doctoral Capstone Project (1.0 unit)
ANST694B.desc: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate. The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

ANST694C.name: ANST 694c: Doctoral Capstone Project (1.0 unit)
ANST694C.desc: Mentored research on an individualized topic of interest leading to the professional doctorate. The project will culminate in a formal written research paper or presentation.

BIOC504.name: Crosslist BIOC 504: Molecular Biology of Cancer (4.0 units)
BIOC504.desc: Epidemiology, pathobiology, carcinogenesis, tumor biology and heterogeneity, retroviruses, oncogenes, cell cycle control, genetics of cancer, tumor immunology, treatment strategies.

BIOC511.name: BIOC 511: Foundations for Molecular Medicine (4.0 units)
BIOC511.desc: Structure, function and metabolism of nucleic acids, proteins, carbohydrates and lipids and related regulatory mechanism including transcription factor and upstream signaling pathways initiated at the cell membrane.

BIOC531.name: Crosslist BIOC 531: Cell Biology (4.0 units)
BIOC531.desc: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intracellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions. Cross-listed as BIOC 531, MICB 531, MPTX 531, PATH 531, PHBI 531, PSCI 531

BIOC561.name: Crosslist BIOC 561: Molecular Biology (4.0 units)
BIOC561.desc: Biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, RNA processing, translation, and regulation of gene expression with emphasis on multicellular eukaryotic organisms and comparisons to prokaryotes.

BIOC575.name: BIOC 575: Predictive and Prognostic Biomarkers in Cancer Treatment (2.0 units)
BIOC575.desc: Exploration of how appropriate biomarkers can predict response to cancer therapy, tumor recurrence after surgery, rapid detection of tumor response and overall prognosis. Recommended preparation: INTD 571 and a basic understanding of molecular biology.

BIOC581.name: BIOC 581: Toolbox for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (4.0 units)
BIOC581.desc: Explores the principles and applications of traditional and state-of-the-art methods in molecular biology and biochemistry with live demonstrations of techniques when feasible.

BIOC590.name: BIOC 590: Directed Research (1.0-12.0 units)
BIOC590.desc: Research leading to the master of science degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree will be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

BIOC596.name: BIOC 596: Internship for Curricular Practical Training (1.0-3.0 units, max 3)
BIOC596.desc: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program with a cumulative 3.0 GPA.

CBG504.name: Crosslist CBG 504: Molecular Biology of Cancer (4.0 units)
CBG504.desc: Epidemiology, pathobiology, carcinogenesis, tumor biology and heterogeneity, retroviruses, oncogenes, cell cycle control, genetics of cancer, tumor immunology, treatment strategies.

CBG790.name: CBG 790: Research (1.0-12.0 units)
CBG790.desc: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

CNB502.name: CNB 502L: Advanced Regional Anatomy I (2.0 units)
CNB502.desc: In-depth dissection of one or more regions of the human body, supplemented with literature research, and teaching practicum. May also enable the student to pursue a minor research investigation in some anatomical region of choice. Focuses on the following anatomical regions: Axial Skeleton, Upper and Lower Limbs, and Thoracic Cavity.

CNB504.name: CNB 504L: Human Skeletal Anatomy (3.0 units)
CNB504.desc: An intensive introduction to the human skeleton and the fundamentals of bone and dental biology. Covers a variety of topics including: skeletal development; functional interpretation of bone and bony processes; osteological and dental pathology; human anatomical variation; laboratory analyses and imaging techniques; methods for estimating age, sex, and stature; and comparative osteology.

CNB511A.name: CNB 511aL: Microscopic Anatomy (3.0 units)
CNB511A.desc: Lectures and laboratory in microscopic anatomy emphasizing embryonic origin of the basic body plan, cells, tissues, and organs; ultrastructural and functional correlations.

CNB531.name: Crosslist CNB 531: Cell Biology (4.0 units)
CNB531.desc: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intracellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions. Cross-listed as BIOC 531, MICB 531, MPTX 531, PATH 531, PHBI 531, PSCI 531

CNB561.name: Crosslist CNB 561: Molecular Biology (4.0 units)
CNB561.desc: Biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, RNA processing, translation, and regulation of gene expression with emphasis on multicellular eukaryotic organisms and comparisons to prokaryotes.

CNB572.name: Crosslist CNB 572: Medical Physiology I (4.0 units)
CNB572.desc: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on muscle, respiratory, cardiovascular and renal systems. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.

CNB580.name: CNB 580L: Gross Anatomy Teaching Practicum I (4.0 units)
CNB580.desc: Obtain a deeper understanding of clinical anatomy, develop pedagogical skills in small-group anatomical demonstration, and learn to prepare practical exams.

DSR620.name: DSR 620: Current Topics in Stem Cell Biology and Organogenesis (1.0 units, max 12)
DSR620.desc: Selected topics on sub-fields within stem cell biology and organogenesis. Includes review of contemporary literature and research. Open only to master and doctoral students.

DSR790.name: DSR 790: Research (1.0-12.0 units)
DSR790.desc: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

HP200.name: HP 200: Introduction to Health Promotion and Disease Prevention (4.0 units)
HP200.desc: Introduction to strategies for promoting health and wellness. Includes self monitoring of health risk behavior, goal setting, and behavior changes.

HP230.name: HP 230: Nutrition and Health (4.0 units)
HP230.desc: Nutrition as it relates to health promotion across the lifespan and disease prevention. Discussion of nutrients, factors affecting food choices, food safety and global nutrition issues.

HP270.name: HP 270: Introduction to Global Health (4.0 units)
HP270.desc: Introduction to concepts of global health and disease control. Issues of globalization, global governance, emerging diseases, infectious disease treatment, and outbreak challenges.

HP290.name: HP 290: Introduction to Research Apprenticeship (2.0 units, max 8)
HP290.desc: Individual research apprenticeship in health related fields under supervision of a departmental faculty member. Graded CR/NC. Departmental approval.

HP300.name: HP 300: Theoretical Principles of Health Behavior (4.0 units)
HP300.desc: Overview and analysis of predictors and consequences of health-related behaviors; theoretical viewpoints and strategies for behavior change. Recommended preparation: HP 200

HP340.name: HP 340Lg: Health Behavior Statistical Methods (4.0 units)
HP340.desc: Intermediate statistics for health behavior studies; topics include descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression, and use of computer software in data analysis.

HP350.name: HP 350L: Health Behavior Research Methods (4.0 units)
HP350.desc: Introduction to the design, conduct and evaluation of health behavior research studies; quantitative and qualitative approaches to research and analysis. Recommended preparation: HP 340L

HP365.name: HP 365mgw: Culture, Lifestyle, and Health (4.0 units)
HP365.desc: Comparison of national and international differences in health status as influenced by cultural practices and lifestyles within geographic, economic, and political environments. (Duplicates Credit in former HP-400m)

HP370.name: HP 370g: Introduction to Epidemiology: Methods and Applications (4.0 units)
HP370.desc: Examines the primary goals and methods of epidemiology, the study of factors that influence health and disease in individuals and populations.

HP408.name: HP 408: Environmental Health in the Community (4.0 units)
HP408.desc: Survey of occupational and environmental health. Introduction to epidemiology, exposure assessment, toxicology, policy development, risk assessment, and effects of urban development on health.

HP420.name: HP 420m: Gender and Minority Health Issues (4.0 units)
HP420.desc: Examines the nature and roots of health disparities among women,men, and different ethnic and age groups; methods for reducing such disparities; strategies for prevention services.

HP421.name: HP 421: Violence as a Public Health Issue (4.0 units)
HP421.desc: Patterns and prevalence of violence; psychosoical, environmental, and biological influences on violent behavior; youth gangs; drugs and violence; family violence; and prevention and intervention strategies.

HP422.name: HP 422: AIDS in Society (4.0 units)
HP422.desc: Provides a broad examination of issues in HIV/AIDS, including behavioral, social, biological, clinical and ethical dimensions of the pandemic in the U.S. and elsewhere.

HP430.name: HP 430: Obesity and Health (4.0 units)
HP430.desc: Examination of causes and consequences of obesity, with emphasis on health risks of type II diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Recommended preparation: HP 230.

HP432.name: HP 432: Clinical Nutrition (4.0 units)
HP432.desc: Metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and protein; introduction to vitamins, minerals and dietary modifications in various pathological conditions. Recommended preparation: HP 230.

HP441.name: HP 441: Health Promotion in the Work Place (4.0 units)
HP441.desc: Covers phases of worksite health promotion: research, design, implementation and evaluation; concerns regarding escalating medical costs and the role of health promotion in offering substitutes.

HP442.name: HP 442: Chronic Disease Epidemiology (4.0 units)
HP442.desc: Overview of causative factors and demographic distributions of the major chronic diseases in the western world; edpidemiologic concepts and research designs. Recommended preparation: HP 320

HP450.name: HP 450: Traditional Eastern Medicine and Modern Health (4.0 units)
HP450.desc: Overview of traditional Eastern approaches toward health and disease; relevance to modern health issues, emphasizing a comparison between traditional Chinese and modern Western medicine. Recommended preparation: Fundamentals of Medicine

HP460.name: HP 460: Adolescent Health (4.0 units)
HP460.desc: Survey of the development of healthy and the prevention of health-risk behaviors during adolescence. Prevention and promotion techniques will be explored emphasizing cultural differences.

HP483.name: Crosslist HP 483: Global Health and Aging (4.0 units)
HP483.desc: Overview of the impact aging populations will have on global institutions from a variety of perspectives. Examination of public health policy issues.

INTD504.name: INTD 504: Molecular Biology of Cancer (4.0 units)
INTD504.desc: Epidemiology, pathobiology, carcinogenesis, tumor biology and heterogeneity, retroviruses, oncogenes, cell cycle control, genetics of cancer, tumor immunology, treatment strategies.

INTD522.name: INTD 522: Infection and Host Responses (4.0 units)
INTD522.desc: Overview of microbes, their life cycles and the host responses they elicit, evade or exploit, including the manipulation and the malfunction of the immune system.

INTD531.name: INTD 531: Cell Biology (4.0 units)
INTD531.desc: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intracellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions. Cross-listed as BIOC 531, MICB 531, MPTX 531, PATH 531, PHBI 531, PSCI 531

INTD550.name: INTD 550: Introduction to Pathology (4.0 units)
INTD550.desc: Normal histology and introduction to basic pathological concepts. Provides a solid and basic understanding of normal structures and how they relate to function.

INTD561.name: INTD 561: Molecular Biology (4.0 units)
INTD561.desc: Biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, RNA processing, translation, and regulation of gene expression with emphasis on multicellular eukaryotic organisms and comparisons to prokaryotes.

INTD572.name: INTD 572: Medical Physiology I (4.0 units)
INTD572.desc: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on muscle, respiratory, cardiovascular and renal systems. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.

INTD596.name: INTD 596: Internship for Curricular Practical Training (1.0-3.0 units, max 3)
INTD596.desc: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

INTD620.name: INTD 620: Medical Students Elective Program (0.0 units)
INTD620.desc: Opportunities for Medical students as preceptors, in research laboratories or in field medical services under guidance of sponsors approved by factulty committees. Graded CR/NC.

INTD622.name: INTD 622: Pre-clinical System Block for Health, Technology & Engineeri (4.0-9.0 units)
INTD622.desc: A three-to-nine week block of lectures and laboratories focused on particular body system (e.g. Cardiovascular, Renal, etc.). Open only to Health, Technology and Engineering students.

INTD790.name: INTD 790: Research (1.0-12.0 units)
INTD790.desc: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

MBPH550.name: MBPH 550: Seminar in Medical Biophysics (1.0 units, max 4)
MBPH550.desc: Seminar course in which students make oral and written presentations based on original research, published journal articles, or research proposals.

MBPH596.name: MBPH 596: Internship for Curricular Practical Training (1.0-3.0 units, max 3)
MBPH596.desc: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

MEDB790.name: MEDB 790: Research (1.0-12.0 units)
MEDB790.desc: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

MEDS220.name: MEDS 220: Preparation for the Clinical Experience (2.0 units)
MEDS220.desc: Discussion and exercises in clinically relevant topics (professional behavior, patient privacy, medical ethics, cultural competency, teamwork, etc.) in preparation for experience in the clinical setting.

MEDS280.name: MEDS 280: The History of Medicine: a Doctor's Perspective (2.0 units)
MEDS280.desc: Explores the role of medicine/surgery in society, whose ideas about health and disease have undergone enormous changes from antiquity to the present day.

MEDS315.name: MEDS 315: Human Anatomy, Physiology, and the Technology of Medicine (2.0 units)
MEDS315.desc: Introduction to human anatomy and physiology in relation to common disease processes, and an examination of how technology has transformed western medicine throughout history.

MEDS320.name: MEDS 320: Human Cadaveric Anatomy (4.0 units)
MEDS320.desc: Anatomical structure and function of the major regions of the human body as related to health and disease, using clinical cases, lectures and cadaveric demonstrations.

MEDS330.name: MEDS 330: Bionics: Solutions to Enable the Disabled (2.0 units)
MEDS330.desc: Focused examination of medical bionics with emphasis on solutions that enable the disabled and detailed discussions and evaluations of the social and technological aspects of bionic medical devices.

MEDS335.name: MEDS 335: Human Development: From Stem to Sternum (2.0 units)
MEDS335.desc: An introduction to transformation of a single cell into a mature organism. Prerequisites: BISC-220L or BISC-221L. Recommended preparation: BISC-320L.

MEDS340.name: MEDS 340: The Brain in Health and Disease (4.0 units)
MEDS340.desc: Study of the human brain with emphasis on structure-functional relationships, illustrative case studies, current imaging techniques, with illustrative laboratory exercises using specimens and slides. Prerequisites: BISC 220L or BISC 221L; CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a. Recommended preparation: MEDS 310.

MEDS350.name: MEDS 350: Neurochemistry of Addiction: Drugs, Brain, and Behavior (2.0 units)
MEDS350.desc: The neurochemistry of psychiatric illness and addiction, introduction to brain and nervous system biochemistry, anatomy and disease states. Covers prescribed medications and drugs of abuse.

MEDS355.name: MEDS 355: Skeletal Biology and Pathology: No Bones About It (2.0 units)
MEDS355.desc: Overview of the cellular make-up of the human skeleton, the functions of bones, clinical application of this knowledge towards bone-related diseases, and introduction to technological advances in orthopedic surgery.

MEDS360.name: MEDS 360: Bench to Bedside: Application of the Basic Sciences (2.0 units)
MEDS360.desc: A theoretical basis of laboratory approaches that help the biomedical or physician scientist in understanding the etiology of disease and targeting disease processes.

MEDS420.name: MEDS 420: Clinical Pediatrics (2.0 units)
MEDS420.desc: Explores enduring and fascinating topics in Pediatrics through a modern lens, incorporating first hand patient-care experiences in clinics and hospitals, and didactic case-based discussions. Prerequisites: BISC 220L or BISC 221L, and MEDS 220.

MEDS425.name: MEDS 425: Medical Examiner-Coroner: Investigating Death (2.0 units)
MEDS425.desc: Emphasizes the team-based approach used by forensic scientists, medical examiners and coroners to investigate the circumstances and determine the cause/manner of death. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.

MEDS440.name: MEDS 440: Introduction to Surgical Principles (2.0 units)
MEDS440.desc: Introduction to the spectrum of surgical care, taught by surgeons, with the goal of developing an appreciation of the role that surgery plays in society. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a and MEDS 220. Open only to juniors and seniors.

MEDS445.name: MEDS 445: Cancer: Introduction to Oncology in the Modern Era (2.0 units)
MEDS445.desc: Introduction to the spectrum of clinical and scientific issues surrounding contemporary cancer care; molecular diagnostics, genomic medicine, modern therapeutics and community/patient engagement.

MEDS455.name: MEDS 455: Integrative Health Care (2.0 units)
MEDS455.desc: Introduction to integrative health care; a holistic approach to medicine combining conventional medical therapies with evidence-informed complementary alternative medicine.

MEDS460.name: MEDS 460: Emergency Health Care (2.0 units)
MEDS460.desc: Principles of emergency medical services, ranging from pre-hospital care and advanced life-saving, to minor injuries and illnesses. Interactive experience with ER physicians/emergency health care providers. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Recommended preparation: MEDS 260.

MEDS490.name: MEDS 490: Directed Research in Biomedical Science (1.0-8.0 units, max 12)
MEDS490.desc: Individual research and readings. Recommended preparation: MEDS 300 and MEDS 360. Not available for graduate credit.Prerequisite: BISC 220 or BISC 221) and CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM115a.

MEDS500.name: MEDS 500: Basic Concepts in Global Health (4.0 units)
MEDS500.desc: Exploration of global health issues facing resource-poor societies; emphasizes contributing factors including behavioral and physiological bases, economic, social, and political context.

MEDS504.name: MEDS 504L: Core Principles System II (4.0 units)
MEDS504.desc: Continuation of concepts from MEDS 503L: basic medical concepts and biological system functions; examination of core principles of science and medical treatment.

MEDS510.name: MEDS 510: Global Health Modules, Malaria (2.0 units)
MEDS510.desc: Critical issues in international control and treatment of malaria. Exploration of biological and epidemiological fundamentals of human-parasite interaction including dynamics of transmission among populations.

MEDS514.name: MEDS 514: Global Health Modules, Tropical Disease (2.0 units)
MEDS514.desc: Examination of prevalent tropical diseases: epidemiology, clinical manifestations, treatment, impact on economies of tropical countries. Key issues related to these diseases; World Health Organization responses.

MEDS516.name: MEDS 516: Cultural Humility in Health and Medicine (2.0 units)
MEDS516.desc: Practical approach to the development of professional skills for providing culturally sensitive clinical health services to ethnically and linguistically diverse patients.

MEDS519.name: MEDS 519: Global Oral Health (2.0 units)
MEDS519.desc: Better understand the key issues impacting global oral health, how better care can help reduce the disease prevalence, and ways to prepare the next generation of global health leaders to address the key issues. Open only to Global Medicine majors.

MEDS530A.name: MEDS 530a: Foundation of Medicine: Anatomy, Physiology, and Pathology (4.0 units)
MEDS530A.desc: Fundamentals of physiology, chemistry, anatomy, biochemistry and microbiology, as well as pharmacological issues, mathematical basis of lab instruments or techniques, and computational modeling

MEDS532.name: MEDS 532: Non-communicable Diseases (2.0 units)
MEDS532.desc: A conceptual framework for understanding global challenges faced in the management of non-communicable diseases, including heart disease, diabetes, chronic lung disease, and cancer.

MEDS554.name: MEDS 554: Clinical Medicine and Healthcare Delivery in Panama (2.0 units)
MEDS554.desc: A two-week course providing students with hands-on experience in the practice of rural medicine as they gain exposure to the various socio-economic factors present in Bocas del Toro, Panama. Recommended preparation: MEDS 500, MEDS 501, MEDS 510, MEDS 511, MEDS 514, MEDS 515. Open only to Global Medicine majors.

MEDS581.name: MEDS 581: Case Studies in Interprofessional Healthcare (4.0 units)
MEDS581.desc: Survey of the specific roles each member of an interprofessional health team plays in the provision of care, based on their professional training. Application of diverse health professional expertise to case studies in healthcare.

MEDS597B.name: MEDS 597b: Health Technology Internship (1.0 unit)
MEDS597B.desc: Internship course on the use of new technology based on sensors and wireless communications to the healthcare industry. Continues material from GM-597a. Open only to M.S., Electrical Engineering (Wireless Health Technology) students. Graded CR/NC.

MICB504.name: Crosslist MICB 504: Molecular Biology of Cancer (4.0 units)
MICB504.desc: Epidemiology, pathobiology, carcinogenesis, tumor biology and heterogeneity, retroviruses, oncogenes, cell cycle control, genetics of cancer, tumor immunology, treatment strategies.

MICB522.name: Crosslist MICB 522: Infection and Host Responses (4.0 units)
MICB522.desc: Overview of microbes, their life cycles and the host responses they elicit, evade or exploit, including the manipulation and the malfunction of the immune system.

MICB531.name: Crosslist MICB 531: Cell Biology (4.0 units)
MICB531.desc: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intracellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions. Cross-listed as BIOC 531, MICB 531, MPTX 531, PATH 531, PHBI 531, PSCI 531

MICB561.name: Crosslist MICB 561: Molecular Biology (4.0 units)
MICB561.desc: Biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, RNA processing, translation, and regulation of gene expression with emphasis on multicellular eukaryotic organisms and comparisons to prokaryotes.

MICB570.name: MICB 570: Microbiology Research Seminar (1.0 units, max 10)
MICB570.desc: Critical discussion of current research topics. Students present published and unpublished research results for discussion and critique. Prerequisite: Current enrollment in Microbiology Ph.D. program.

MICB572.name: Crosslist MICB 572: Medical Physiology I (4.0 units)
MICB572.desc: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on muscle, respiratory, cardiovascular and renal systems. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.

MPHY572.name: Crosslist MPHY 572: Medical Physiology I (4.0 units)
MPHY572.desc: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on muscle, respiratory, cardiovascular and renal systems. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.

MPHY590.name: MPHY 590: Directed Research (1.0-12.0 units)
MPHY590.desc: Research leading to the masters degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to master students. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PHBI-590.)

MPHY596.name: MPHY 596: Internship for Curricular Practical Training (1.0-3.0 units, max 3)
MPHY596.desc: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program.

MSS790.name: MSS 790: Research (1.0-12.0 units)
MSS790.desc: Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Open only to doctoral students. Graded CR/NC.

NIIN500.name: NIIN 500: Neuroimaging and Systems Neuroscience (3.0 units)
NIIN500.desc: Overview of elemental neuroanatomy and brain systems with an emphasis on a neuroimaging perspective in the human and mouse. Open only to Neuroimaging and Informatics majors.

NIIN510.name: NIIN 510: Fundamentals of Human Neuroimaging (3.0 units)
NIIN510.desc: Survey of anatomical and functional neuroimaging approaches and their use to explore the healthy as well as diseased human brain. Open only to Neuroimaging and Informatics majors.

NIIN530.name: NIIN 530: Neuroimaging Data Acquisition w/ Magnetic Resonance Imaging (3.0 units)
NIIN530.desc: Introduces the various approaches used to image the living brain using MR-based techniques. Covers neuroimaging scanning technologies, pulse sequence design, and sources of image artifact. Recommended preparation: familiarity with Matlab. Open only to Neuroimaging and Informatics majors.

NIIN597.name: NIIN 597: Current Topics in Neuroimaging Informatics (1.0 unit)
NIIN597.desc: Leading researchers in the areas of basic and clinical brain imaging, computational methods, and informatics formally discuss their work for which students provide written critical review and comment.

PAIN703.name: PAIN 703: Psychological Aspects of the Pain Experience: Individual and (2.0 units)
PAIN703.desc: Explore the psychological and social perspectives that influence chronic pain, reinforcing the need to look beyond the initial physical diagnosis.

PAIN708.name: PAIN 708: Opioids (1.0 unit)
PAIN708.desc: Explores opioid therapeutics including proper use, dosing, side effects and its management, use in special populations, and legal/ethical considerations for prescribers and dispensers.

PAIN710.name: PAIN 710: Advanced Pain Physiology and Neuroscience (1.0 unit)
PAIN710.desc: Advanced neurophysiology of pain including immunology and epigenetics, neuropathic pain, inflammation, with a series of lectures and sessions to analyze clinical cases.

PATH531.name: Crosslist PATH 531: Cell Biology (4.0 units)
PATH531.desc: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intracellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions. Cross-listed as BIOC 531, MICB 531, MPTX 531, PATH 531, PHBI 531, PSCI 531

PATH550.name: Crosslist PATH 550: Introduction to Pathology (4.0 units)
PATH550.desc: Normal histology and introduction to basic pathological concepts. Provides a solid and basic understanding of normal structures and how they relate to function.

PATH553.name: PATH 553: Methods in Cellular and Clinical Pathology (3.0 units)
PATH553.desc: Includes advanced techniques in cell biology, protein and immunochemistry. A practical approach to acquaint new graduate students with current methodologies and applications used in biomedical research. Duplicates credit in former PATH 552a.

PATH561.name: Crosslist PATH 561: Molecular Biology (4.0 units)
PATH561.desc: Biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, RNA processing, translation, and regulation of gene expression with emphasis on multicellular eukaryotic organisms and comparisons to prokaryotes.

PATH570A.name: PATH 570a: Seminar in Pathology (1.0 unit)
PATH570A.desc: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH570B.name: PATH 570b: Seminar in Pathology (1.0 unit)
PATH570B.desc: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH570C.name: PATH 570c: Seminar in Pathology (1.0 unit)
PATH570C.desc: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH570D.name: PATH 570d: Seminar in Pathology (1.0 unit)
PATH570D.desc: Recent advances in the understanding of diseased cells and tissues are reported and discussed using standard seminars, as well as autopsy organ reviews.

PATH572.name: Crosslist PATH 572: Medical Physiology I (4.0 units)
PATH572.desc: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on muscle, respiratory, cardiovascular and renal systems. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.

PHBI524.name: Crosslist PHBI 524: Advanced Overview of Neurosciences (4.0 units)
PHBI524.desc: Study of the nervous system at multiple levels through the analysis of four themes: Motor Control; Emotion, Motivation, and Decision-Making; Memory and Learning; and Vision. Prerequisites: BISC 421. Open only to master and doctoral students. (Duplicates credit in former NEUR 524.)

PHBI531.name: Crosslist PHBI 531: Cell Biology (4.0 units)
PHBI531.desc: Current perspectives on major research areas in cell biology. Emphasis will be on in-depth examination of cellular structures, regulatory processes, intracellular routing and targeting, and cell/environmental interactions. Cross-listed as BIOC 531, MICB 531, MPTX 531, PATH 531, PHBI 531, PSCI 531

PHBI550.name: PHBI 550: Seminar in Advanced Cellular, Molecular and Systemic Physiology (1.0 units, max 12)
PHBI550.desc: Lectures and student presentations on advanced topics in molecular, cellular and systemic physiology. Open to Systems Biology and Disease, Physiology and Biophysics, and Pathobiology students only. Graded CR/NC.

PHBI561.name: Crosslist PHBI 561: Molecular Biology (4.0 units)
PHBI561.desc: Biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, RNA processing, translation, and regulation of gene expression with emphasis on multicellular eukaryotic organisms and comparisons to prokaryotes.

PHBI572.name: Crosslist PHBI 572: Medical Physiology I (4.0 units)
PHBI572.desc: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on muscle, respiratory, cardiovascular and renal systems. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.

PHBI660.name: PHBI 660: Understanding Diseases of Ion Transport (2.0 units)
PHBI660.desc: Examination of the genetics, biochemical mechanisms, and physiological characteristics of diseases caused by inherited mutations in ion channels and ion transport proteins.

PM500.name: PM 500: Foundations of Health Behavior (4.0 units)
PM500.desc: Overview of behavioral theory and research in disease prevention and health promotion and in adaptation to chronic disease, including an introduction to measures of outcomes. Prerequisite: Admission to HBR Ph.D. Program or permission of instructor.

PM501.name: PM 501: Foundations in Health Education and Promotion (4.0 units)
PM501.desc: Overview and application of behavioral theories to the field of health education and promotion. Examines the determinants of health behavior and strategies for change at the individual, group and community level.

PM502.name: PM 502: Foundations of Public Health (4.0 units)
PM502.desc: Overview of public health concepts and issues, including population health; ethics; health disparities, determinants, and systems of care; global health; policy; health promotion; environmental health.

PM506.name: PM 506: Overcoming Real World Challenges in Global Health (4.0 units)
PM506.desc: Overview of program implementation challenges in global health contexts, including best practices for establishing effective cross-cultural collaborations, working with key leaders, and operationalizing complex interventions.

PM507.name: PM 507: Public Health Services Research Methods (4.0 units)
PM507.desc: A practical examination of methods and data sources used to evaluate public health services and conduct policy research and evaluation within health care delivery systems.

PM508.name: PM 508: Health Service Delivery in the U.S. (4.0 units)
PM508.desc: Historical development of the American health care system; determinants of health care utilization; role of health care providers; health policy; public health services; and health care finance.

PM509.name: PM 509: Comparative Health Care Systems (4.0 units)
PM509.desc: Macro-level analysis of the structure and delivery of health care services around the world, including an examination and comparison of health system performance.

PM510.name: PM 510L: Principles of Biostatistics (4.0 units)
PM510.desc: Concepts of biostatistics; appropriate uses and common misuses of health statistics; practice in the application of statistical procedures; introduction to statistical software including EXCEL, SPSS, nQuery. Laboratory.

PM511A.name: PM 511aL: Data Analysis (4.0 units)
PM511A.desc: Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.

PM511B.name: PM 511bL: Data Analysis (4.0 units)
PM511B.desc: Statistical methods for analysis of categorical data including dichotomous, ordinal, multinomial and count data, using Stata package. Includes laboratory.

PM511C.name: PM 511cL: Data Analysis (4.0 units)
PM511C.desc: Methods and applications for modeling longitudinal, time-to-event and multi- level data. Includes laboratory using R package. Lecture 2 hrs; laboratory 2 hrs. Prerequisites: PM-511b.

PM512.name: PM 512: Principles of Epidemiology (4.0 units)
PM512.desc: Terminology/uses of epidemiology and demography; sources/uses of population data; types of epidemiologic studies; risk assessment; common sources of bias in population studies; principles of screening. Recommended preparation: algebra

PM517A.name: PM 517a: Research Methods in Epidemiology (3.0 units)
PM517A.desc: Study design, ascertainment of study objects, questionnaire development, various methodological issues in study design and interpretation including bias, measurement error, confounding and effect modification.

PM522A.name: PM 522a: Introduction to the Theory of Statistics (3.0 units)
PM522A.desc: a: Density distribution and hazard functions; normal, chi-square, student's t and F distributions; and sampling procedures for single factor and multiple factor designs, distributions. Recommended preparation: working knowledge of multivariable calculus and familiarity with linear algebra.

PM525.name: PM 525: Culture and Health: Global Perspectives (4.0 units)
PM525.desc: International variations in health status with a focus on the impact of socioeconomic status, politics, environment, education and gender in etiology of illness, access to health care, progression of disease, and recovery.

PM529.name: PM 529: Environmental Health: An Epidemiological Approach (4.0 units)
PM529.desc: An overview of environmental health, identifying issues in assessing effects of exposure on health and potential interventions for reducing adverse health risks. Prerequisite: PM-512

PM533.name: PM 533: Genetic and Molecular Epidemiology (3.0 units)
PM533.desc: Genetic principles; design and analysis of family studies; introduction to likelihood estimation; segregation and linkage analysis; biomarkers of exposure, susceptibility, and disease; laboratory methods; susceptibility genes; association and linkage disequilibrium.

PM536.name: PM 536: Program Evaluation and Research (4.0 units)
PM536.desc: Overview of concepts, tools, data collection, analysis methods and designs used to evaluate health promotion programs. Examples from substance abuse prevention, family planning and reproductive health programs.

PM537.name: PM 537: Chronic Disease Epidemiology (4.0 units)
PM537.desc: Overview of causative factors and demographic distribution of major chronic diseases in the western world. Epidemiologic concepts, methods and research design as applied to chronic disease prevention will be emphasized. Prerequisite: PM 512.

PM544.name: PM 544L: Multivariate Analysis (3.0 units)
PM544.desc: Exploratory and inferential techniques for multivariate data, Hotelling's T2, multivariate analysis of variance, classification analysis, principle components, cluster analysis, factor analysis. Involves computer use.

PM552.name: PM 552: Statistical Methods in Clinical Trials (3.0 units)
PM552.desc: Stochastic failure process; parametric models for survival data; sample size estimation procedures for clinical trials; multivariate regression models for binary outcome and censored survival data; computer programs; multiple failure modes and competing risks.

PM555.name: PM 555: Environmental Health, Policy and Practice (4.0 units)
PM555.desc: Examination of environmental public health policies/regulations, the role of science in assessment and policy initiatives, barriers to change, and competing interests that influence policy adoption. Recommended preparation: PM-529.

PM558.name: PM 558: Environmental Epidemiology: Concepts, Methods, and Practice (4.0 units)
PM558.desc: Examine epidemiologic methods, concepts, and statistical approaches; case-study seminars with structured critiques of current literature on human-environment interactions affecting public health. Recommended preparation: PM-510 and PM-512.

PM559.name: PM 559: Cancer Epidemiology (4.0 units)
PM559.desc: Explores the fundamental concepts of cancer epidemiology, including the molecular basis, descriptive epidemiology, and historical and groundbreaking studies that have impacted the field.

PM563.name: PM 563: Organizing and Mobilizing Communities for Public Health (4.0 units)
PM563.desc: Survey of effective community organizing and mobilization efforts in the U.S. and abroad, using participatory, organizational, community empowerment and public-private partnership models.

PM564.name: PM 564: Public Health Leadership and Management (4.0 units)
PM564.desc: Introduction to leadership and management concepts, tools, and practices in the context of domestic and global public health and healthcare delivery settings.

PM565.name: PM 565: Introduction to Global Health (4.0 units)
PM565.desc: Current public health issues and research topics relating to 21st century challenges and threats. Lessons learned and best practices to strengthen public health systems and enhance public health readiness and preparedness.

PM567.name: PM 567: Public Health Disaster Management and Response (4.0 units)
PM567.desc: Definition and chronology of natural and man-made disasters and their effects on the global community. Structure and organization of disaster management systems and the role of humanitarian organizations.

PM568.name: PM 568: Ethical Issues in Public Health (4.0 units)
PM568.desc: Ethical principles in the distribution of health resources, conduct of global public health research, and implementation of public health initiatives across different nations, cultures, religions.

PM569.name: PM 569: Spatial Statistics (3.0 units)
PM569.desc: An introduction to statistical methods for analyzing and interpreting spatially referenced data topics include: geostatistics, areal data, point pattern data and visualization.

PM572.name: Crosslist PM 572: Medical Physiology I (4.0 units)
PM572.desc: Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on muscle, respiratory, cardiovascular and renal systems. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.

PM575.name: PM 575: Statistical Methods in Environmental Epidemiology (3.0 units)
PM575.desc: Study designs, exposure time response, longitudinal, spatial, ecologic correlation and mechanistic models, measurement error interactions, measurement error, public policy implications.

PM580.name: PM 580: Foundations of Child Health (4.0 units)
PM580.desc: Overview of issues related to infant, child, and adolescent health, including special health considerations at different points in the developmental cycle, health care systems and policies, and health disparities.

PM585.name: PM 585: Child Health Policy (4.0 units)
PM585.desc: History of child health and social welfare programs during the past century. Issues examining health status and health service delivery, the role of health care financing, and health policy.

PM588.name: PM 588: The Practice of Epidemiology (4.0 units)
PM588.desc: Provides students with hands on experience of the common methods used in conducting epidemiological studies, and designing and obtaining funding for research projects. Prerequisite: PM-512. Recommended preparation: PM 527.

PM595.name: PM 595: Internship for Curricular Practical Training (1.0-3.0 units, max 3)
PM595.desc: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the students field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty.

PM596.name: PM 596: Practicum in Public Health (1.0 unit)
PM596.desc: Applied practical experience through field placement in federal, state, and/or local public health agencies/organizations, including community-based organizations; research and school-based settings.

PM605.name: PM 605: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis (4.0 units)
PM605.desc: Theoretical basis and practical approaches for identifying, summarizing and interpreting current bodies of scholarly information addressing a defined research question.

PM610.name: PM 610: Seminar in Biostatistics and Epidemiology (1.0 units, max 4)
PM610.desc: Special topics of current interest to provide background for research in biostatistics and epidemiology. Based largely on student dissertation research. Graded CR/NC.

PM612A.name: PM 612a: Clinical Translational Research (CTR) (4.0 units)
PM612A.desc: First of three courses in CTR, a discipline that fosters multidirectional integration of basic, patient-oriented and population-based research with long-term goal of improving public health. Recommended preparation: PM 510.

PM615.name: PM 615: Intervention Research Grant Proposal Development (4.0 units)
PM615.desc: Process of applying for research grants in health behavior research, including dissertation grants. Covers the structure of NIH and other grantmaking agencies, the grant review process, tailoring ideas to the grantmaker's priorities, research design, development of training and mentoring plans, and budgeting.

PM756.name: PM 756: Research Seminar in Health Behavior (1.0 units, max 6)
PM756.desc: Short seminar presentations and discussions on issues accompanying the development of the field of health behavior and implementation of research in this field. Graded CR/NC.

PCPA503.name: PCPA 503: Behavioral Sciences I (4.0 units)
PCPA503.desc: Current concepts of behavioral medicine as applied to providing health care to diverse populations and investigations of medical care organization and the physician assistant. Open to Physician Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA509.name: PCPA 509: Behavioral Sciences III (4.0 units)
PCPA509.desc: In a seminar format, information management and research methods are explored as well as ethical issues of PA practice will be discussed. Open to Physician Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA523.name: PCPA 523: Clinical Skills I (4.0 units)
PCPA523.desc: Laboratory experiences with basic clinical skills essential to medical practice. First of four courses. Open to Physician Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA529.name: PCPA 529: Clinical Skills III (6.0 units)
PCPA529.desc: Laboratory experiences with basic clinical skills essential to medical practice. Third of four courses. Open to Physician Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA530.name: PCPA 530: Basic Medical Sciences (6.0 units)
PCPA530.desc: A one semester overview of clinical anatomy, physiology, pathophysiology, and pathology essential to understanding disease mechanisms commonly encountered in primary care and specialty practices of medicine. Open to physician assistant practice majors only.

PCPA543.name: PCPA 543: Topics in Medicine I (4.0 units)
PCPA543.desc: Basic instruction in normal/abnormal states of organ systems in the study of disease. The first of three courses that includes instruction in pathophysiology, pharmacology, diagnostic studies, and medicine. Open to Physician Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA549.name: PCPA 549: Topics in Medicine III (6.0 units)
PCPA549.desc: Basic instruction in normal/abnormal states of organ systems in the study of human disease. The third of three courses that includes instruction in pathophysiology, pharmacology, diagnostic studies, and medicine. Open to Physician Assistant Practice majors only.

PCPA563.name: PCPA 563: Clinical Assignment III (3.5 units)
PCPA563.desc: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in a program-approved clinical setting. Requires departmental approval. Graded CR/NC.

PCPA566.name: PCPA 566: Clinical Assignment VI (3.5 units)
PCPA566.desc: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in a program-appoved clinical setting. Requires departmental approval. Graded CR/NC.

PCPA567.name: PCPA 567: Clinical Assignment VII (3.5 units)
PCPA567.desc: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in a program-approved clinical setting. Requires departmental approval. Graded CR/NC.

PCPA568.name: PCPA 568: Clinical Assignment VIII (3.5 units)
PCPA568.desc: One discrete consecutive six-week long, five-day-a-week intensive field placement under a program approved supervising preceptor in a program-approved clinical setting. Requires departmental approval. Graded CR/NC.

SCRM511.name: SCRM 511: Developmental Biology and Human Embryology (4.0 units)
SCRM511.desc: Survey of anatomical, cellular and molecular processes that underlie human development and congenital malformations, with discussion of other species for comparison. Open only to Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine majors.

SCRM513.name: SCRM 513: Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine (4.0 units)
SCRM513.desc: A comprehensive investigation of embryonic, fetal and adult stem cells and the application of stem cell biology to treat disease. Open only to Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine majors.

SCRM580.name: SCRM 580: SCRM External Speaker Seminar Series (2.0 units, max 8)
SCRM580.desc: Reading and discussion of recent papers by the SCRM speaker of the week, and attendance at the speaker's seminar. Open only to Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine majors.

SCRM590.name: SCRM 590: Independent Research (1.0-4.0 units, max 16)
SCRM590.desc: Independent research conducted under the guidance of faculty in the Department of Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine. Prerequisites: SCRM 511, SCRM 513, SCRM 515, SCRM 522, SCRM 524, SCRM 555, SCRM 580. Open only to Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine majors. Graded CR/NC.

SCRM620.name: Crosslist SCRM 620: Current Topics in Stem Cell Biology and Organogenesis (1.0 units, max 12)
SCRM620.desc: Selected topics on sub-fields within stem cell biology and organogenesis. Includes review of contemporary literature and research. Open only to master and doctoral students.

TRGN510.name: TRGN 510: Basic Foundations in Translational Biomedical Informatics (4.0 units)
TRGN510.desc: Translational biomedical informatics analysis of next-generation sequencing genomic data, fundamentals, foundations, and concepts for applied analysis, human ontology, application molecular tools, basic computing.

TRGN514.name: TRGN 514: Introduction to Human Genomic Analysis Methods (4.0 units)
TRGN514.desc: Translational next generation sequencing genomics microarrays, RNA-seq, exome sequencing, annotation, transcriptome, ontology, pipelines, variants, expression, methylation.

TRGN524.name: TRGN 524: Applications of Genomic Technology in Biomedical Research I (4.0 units)
TRGN524.desc: Molecular biotechnology, genomics, next-generation sequencing, epigenomics, drug discovery, biomarkers, microrarrays, commercialization, microarray analysis, expression, proteomics.

TRGN526.name: TRGN 526: Clinical Bioinformatics in Genomic Testing (2.0 units)
TRGN526.desc: Covers basic understandings of clinical bioinformatics methodologies and practices, along with the genomic technologies used for clinical diagnostic purposes.

TRGN536.name: TRGN 536: Biotechnology Primer (4.0 units)
TRGN536.desc: Examination of classical and novel techniques used to explore and manipulate gene function and implications for the use of biotechnology in areas of global need. Recommended preparation: two semesters of introductory biology; two semesters of molecular biology and genetics.

TRGN543.name: TRGN 543: Biotechnology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization I (2.0 units)
TRGN543.desc: Global biotechnology industry, idea generation, business plan formulation, intellectual property protection, funding, personnel management including board composition, regulatory body interaction, company exits.

TRGN546.name: TRGN 546: Biotechnology Intellectual Property, Regulatory, and Corpora (2.0 units)
TRGN546.desc: Core concepts in intellectual property law, regulatory law, healthcare law, corporate law, and M&A law to the biopharmaceutical and diagnostic device sectors. Open to students who are pursuing or have already attained graduate degrees (MS, PhD or PharmD) in the bioscience disciplines, or students from professional schools who have college-level bioscience background.

TRGN550.name: TRGN 550: Communicating Science: Writing (1.0 unit)
TRGN550.desc: Written communication modalities for accurate and effective transmission of scientific information to a wide audience in biomedical, healthcare, and related industries.

TRGN551.name: TRGN 551: Communicating Science: Speaking (1.0 unit)
TRGN551.desc: Verbal communication modalities for accurate and effective transmission of scientific information to a wide audience in biomedical, healthcare, and related industries.

AME101.name: AME 101L: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering and Graphics (3.0 units)
AME101.desc: Gateway to the bachelor of science degree in mechanical engineering. Introduction to mechanical engineering disciplines and practice; graphical communication and layout of machine parts; introduction to computer-aided drafting and drawing.

AME105.name: AME 105: Introduction to Aerospace Engineering (4.0 units)
AME105.desc: Gateway to the Aerospace Engineering major. Introduction to flight vehicle performance and propulsion. Elements of the physics of gases. Laboratory: computers and graphics; model rocket and glider test flights.

AME201.name: AME 201: Statics (3.0 units)
AME201.desc: Analysis of forces acting on particles and rigid bodies in static equilibrium; equivalent systems of forces; friction; centroids and moments of inertia; introduction to energy methods.

AME204.name: AME 204: Strength of Materials (3.0 units)
AME204.desc: Stress, strain and deflection of mechanical elements due to tension, shear, bending, or torsion; combined loads; energy methods, statically indeterminate structures; strength-based design.

AME301.name: AME 301: Dynamics (3.0 units)
AME301.desc: 2-D and 3-D kinematics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies; systems of particles and rigid bodies; coupled rigid bodies; introduction to vibrations.

AME302.name: AME 302: Dynamic Systems (3.0 units)
AME302.desc: Modeling of lumped parameter elements and systems; free and forced response of first and second order systems; design oriented approach to dynamic systems.

AME305.name: AME 305: Mechanical Design (3.0 units)
AME305.desc: Design and analysis of mechanical elements including shafts, bearings, springs, screws, belts, and gears; strength, fatigue, and deflection considerations in machine design.

AME308.name: AME 308: Computer-Aided Analyses for Aero-Mechanical Design (3.0 units)
AME308.desc: Introduction to the finite element method; practical application of computer analysis tools for structural analysis and design. Prerequisite: AME 204. Corequisite: AME 301.

AME309.name: AME 309: Dynamics of Fluids (4.0 units)
AME309.desc: Fluid statics; conservation of mass, momentum, and energy in integral and differential form; applications. Laminar and turbulent pipe flow; compressible flow; potential flow over bodies.

AME331.name: AME 331: Heat Transfer (3.0 units)
AME331.desc: General principles underlying heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation; steady and transient conditions; heat exchangers. Prerequisite: AME-310. Co-requisite: AME-309 or CE-309.

AME341A.name: AME 341a: Mechoptronics Laboratory I and II (3.0 units)
AME341A.desc: A coordinated laboratory and lecture sequence on aeromechanical instrumentation and device control stressing the symbiotic integration of mechanical, optical and electronic components.

AME404.name: AME 404: Computational Solutions to Engineering Problems (3.0 units)
AME404.desc: Mathematical aspects of the solutions to typical advanced mechanical engineering problems. Modeling, simulation, computational aspects, computer solutions, and computational tools. Recommended preparation: FORTRAN, MATLAB, and Maple

AME408.name: AME 408: Computer-Aided Design of Mechanical Systems (3.0 units)
AME408.desc: Design of mechanical systems using advanced graphics techniques; computer-aided drafting, design optimization, elements of computer graphics, solids modeling; introduction to computer-aided manufacturing. Prerequisite: AME 204 or CE 225. Recommended preparation: AME 308.

AME410.name: AME 410: Engineering Design Theory and Methodology (3.0 units)
AME410.desc: Product planning and task clarification, voice of customers, quality function deployment, conceptual and embodiment design, axiomatic theory of design, product quality and manufacturability, design decision-making. Junior standing. Recommended preparation: AME 305

AME415.name: AME 415: Turbine Design and Analysis (3.0 units)
AME415.desc: Physics of turbine operation; design and analysis for the development of turbine hardware for propulsion and power generation. Recommended preparation: Familiarity with Matlab.

AME430.name: AME 430: Thermal Systems Design (3.0 units)
AME430.desc: Design methodology for thermal systems; boilers, condensers, air conditioning, power generation, air pollution control, combustion and alternative fuels. Prerequisite: AME-331; Recommended preparation: AME-312.

AME451.name: AME 451: Linear Control Systems I (3.0 units)
AME451.desc: Transform methods, block diagrams; transfer functions; stability; root-locus and frequency domain analysis and design; state space and multiloop systems. Prerequisites: AME 302 and MATH-245. (Duplicates credit in EE-482)

AME457.name: AME 457: Engineering Fluid Dynamics (3.0 units)
AME457.desc: Laminar and turbulent boundary layer flow with and without heat transfer; boundary layer separation, stability, transition and control; introduction to compressible fluid flow.

AME461.name: Crosslist AME 461: Formation Data Sensing with Well Logs (4.0 units)
AME461.desc: Measurement theory and petroleum/geothermal applications of electrical, radioactive, acoustic, and production logging tools. Estimation of rock porosity, water saturation, permeability, shale content, gas flow rate.

AME463.name: Crosslist AME 463L: Introduction to Transport Processes in Porous Media (4.0 units)
AME463.desc: Fundamentals of flow and transport in porous materials including: Properties of porous rocks, capillarity effect, single- and multiphase flow, diffusion and dispersion in miscible displacements.

AME465.name: Crosslist AME 465L: Drilling Technology and Subsurface Methods (3.0 units)
AME465.desc: Theory and practice in drilling technology; mechanical properties of reservoir rocks; well completion; acidizing and fracturing, oilproduction gechnology. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 3 hours

AME485.name: AME 485: Aerospace Structures I (3.0 units)
AME485.desc: Design, qualification, and workmanship verification of aerospace structures. Analysis for assessing buckling and crippling, welds, and analysis of connections and thin-walled structures.

AME491.name: AME 491: Undergraduate Design Projects II (1.0 units, max 4)
AME491.desc: Analysis, design, fabrication, and evaluation of devices intended for entry in local and national design competitions. Intended for students with prior project experience. Upper division standing. Graded CR/NC.

AME502.name: AME 502: Modern Topics in Aerospace Design (3.0 units)
AME502.desc: Current topics in Aerospace Engineering are addressed by a number of industry panelists. Students, under panelists' supervision and guidance, complete independent research reports and briefings. Recommended preparation: AME 261, AME 441, AME 481 or equivalents. Genuine interest in design of flight vehicles. Open only to Senior, Master, and Doctoral students.

AME504.name: Crosslist AME 504: Mechatronic Systems Engineering (3.0 units)
AME504.desc: Use of mechanical, electrical, and computer engineering, math, and computer science to design of high performance and sophisticated products and processes and systems involving mechatronic.

AME506.name: AME 506: Continuum Mechanics (4.0 units)
AME506.desc: A unified mathematical description for modeling the mechanics and thermodynamics of continua, including topics like elasticity, inelastic material modeling and fluid behavior.

AME507.name: Crosslist AME 507: Mechanics of Solids I (3.0 units)
AME507.desc: Analysis of stress and strain; constitutive equations for elastic materials; plane stress and strain; torsion; introduction to plates and shells; energy methods.

AME513A.name: AME 513a: Fundamentals and Applications of Combustion (4.0 units)
AME513A.desc: Chemical equilibrium, flame temperature, chemical kinetics, transport phenomena, conservation equations of multi-component reacting flows, laminar flames, droplet combustion, flame speed, combustion pollutants, atmospheric pollution processes.

AME515.name: AME 515: Advanced Heat and Mass Diffusion (4.0 units)
AME515.desc: Analytical techniques for heat and mass diffusion problems in various geometries; application to heat/mass transfer in solids, liquids, porous media and bioporous materials.

AME521.name: AME 521: Engineering Vibrations II (4.0 units)
AME521.desc: Multi-degree of freedom systems; continuous systems; modal analysis. Beams, rods, membranes, plates, shells. Approximate methods; Galerkin, Rayleigh Ritz; assumed-mode, finite elements.

AME522.name: AME 522: Nonlinear Dynamical Systems, Vibrations, and Chaos (4.0 units)
AME522.desc: Flows on a line and circle; phase plane methods; bifurcation theory; limit cycle/relaxation oscillations; chaotic systems, one-dimensional maps, the Lorenz equations, fractals and strange attractors.

AME525.name: AME 525: Engineering Analysis (4.0 units)
AME525.desc: Engineering mathematical methods: linear algebra, eigen problems, introduction to linear partial differential equations, transforms and complex variable theory.

AME527.name: AME 527: Elements of Vehicle and Energy Systems Design (3.0 units)
AME527.desc: Design synthesis of aero/hydro/mechanical systems; techniques of design; conceptual thinking; problem definition, configurational development, analytic engineering approximation, oral briefings and group problem solving. Graduate standing.

AME528A.name: Crosslist AME 528a: Finite Element Analysis (3.0 units)
AME528A.desc: Basic concepts; stiffness method; variational methods; displacement method; isoparametric formulation; plane stress and strain; plates and shells; dynamics; stability; nonlinear analysis, heat transfer; computer applications.

AME530A.name: AME 530a: Dynamics of Incompressible Fluids (4.0 units)
AME530A.desc: A unified discussion of low-speed fluid mechanics including exact solutions; approximation techniques for low and high Reynolds numbers; inviscid flows; surface waves; dynamic stability; turbulence.

AME535A.name: AME 535a: Introduction to Computational Fluid Mechanics (3.0 units)
AME535A.desc: Convergence, consistency, stability: finite difference, finite element, and spectral methods; direct and iterative procedures for steady problems; linear diffusion and advection problems; nonlinear advection problems. Recommended preparation: AME 526.

AME541.name: AME 541: Linear Control Systems II (4.0 units)
AME541.desc: State space representation, linearization, solution of state equations; controllability and observability; state feedback, state observers; optimal control; output feedback.

AME547.name: AME 547: Foundations for Manufacturing Automation (3.0 units)
AME547.desc: Fundamentals of contemporary manufacturing automation; underlying building blocks of the automation system; mechanics-based models for designing automation system; and physical and decision-making aspects of automation.

AME549.name: Crosslist AME 549: Systems Architecting (3.0 units)
AME549.desc: Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace, electrical, computer, and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics.

AME551.name: Crosslist AME 551: Mechanical Behavior of Engineering Materials (4.0 units)
AME551.desc: Mechanical properties of materials; macroscopic mechanical behavior related to structure and microstructure of the material; elementary dislocation theory related to basic strengthening mechanisms; fatigue and fracture; nanomaterials.

AME554.name: AME 554: Additive Manufacturing Technologies (3.0 units)
AME554.desc: Working principles of commonly used additive manufacturing processes. Process models and cost estimation methods; current applications and future directions.

AME578.name: AME 578: Modern Alternative Energy Conversion Devices (3.0 units)
AME578.desc: Alternative energy/power conversion including fuel cells, photovoltaic, batteries, and biologically inspired energy processes; biomass conversion and utilization; environmental implications of alternative energy processes.

AME588.name: Crosslist AME 588: Materials Selection (4.0 units)
AME588.desc: Materials selection in relationship to design and fabrication, economic considerations, methodology of selection, performance parameters; case studies.

AME599.name: AME 599: Special Topics (2.0-4.0 units, max 9)
AME599.desc: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering.

ASTE101.name: ASTE 101L: Introduction to Astronautics (4.0 units)
ASTE101.desc: Gateway to the Astronautical Engineering major. Introduction to space, space exploration and the space business. Elements of orbits, spacecraft systems, rocket propulsion, and communications. Laboratory: introduction to graphics, computation and simulation.

ASTE291.name: ASTE 291: Team Projects I (1.0 units, max 4)
ASTE291.desc: Participation in ASTE undergraduate student team projects. Intended for lower-division students or those with little prior project experience. Departmental approval.

ASTE331A.name: ASTE 331a: Spacecraft Systems Engineering (3.0 units)
ASTE331A.desc: Introduction to spacecraft systems: propulsion, attitude dynamics and control, structures, communications, power, thermal control. Space environment. Systems engineering as applied to spacecraft.

ASTE470.name: ASTE 470: Spacecraft Propulsion (3.0 units)
ASTE470.desc: Introduction to rocket engineering. Space missions and thrust requirements. Compressible gas dynamics. Propellant chemistry and thermodynamics. Liquid-and-solid-fueled rockets. Nuclear and electric propulsion. Senior or graduate standing.

ASTE505A.name: ASTE 505a: Plasma Dynamics (3.0 units)
ASTE505A.desc: Charged particle dynamics. Kinetic and fluid theories. Rarefied and collisional plasma flows. Plasma-surface interactions. Waves, instabilities, turbulence. Applications in engineering and space technology. Recommended preparation: Graduate standing in engineering or physics. (Duplicates credit in EE-572a)

ASTE520.name: ASTE 520: Spacecraft System Design (3.0 units)
ASTE520.desc: System components; vehicle structure, propulsion systems, flight dynamics, thermal control, power systems, telecommunication. Interfaces and tradeoffs between these components. Testing, system reliability, and integration.

ASTE524.name: ASTE 524: Human Spaceflight (3.0 units)
ASTE524.desc: Engineering, technologies, and systems for human spaceflight. Life support, space environments, crew accommodations. Mission operations, safety. Astrodynamics, launch and space vehicles, space stations, planetary bases.

ASTE527.name: ASTE 527: Space Exploration Architectures Concept Synthesis Studio (3.0 units)
ASTE527.desc: Programmatic/conceptual design synthesis/choice creation methods for complex space missions. Aerospace system engineering/architecting tools to create innovative projects. Evaluated by faculty/industry/NASA experts. Graduate standing in engineering or science. Recommended preparation: ASTE-520 or experience in space industry

ASTE535.name: ASTE 535: Space Environments and Spacecraft Interactions (3.0 units)
ASTE535.desc: Space environments and interactions with space systems. Vacuum, neutral and ionized species, plasma, radiation, micrometeoroids. Phenomena important for spacecraft operations.

ASTE554.name: ASTE 554: Spacecraft Sensors (3.0 units)
ASTE554.desc: Spacecraft sensors from concepts and design to building, testing, interfacing, integrating, and operations. Optical and infrared sensors, radiometers, radars, phased arrays, signal processing, noise reduction. Graduate standing in engineering or science. Recommended preparation: ASTE 520.

ASTE557.name: ASTE 557: Spacecraft Structural Strength and Materials (3.0 units)
ASTE557.desc: Spacecraft structural strength analysis and design concepts overview; spacecraft material selection; analysis of composite materials; finite element method; spacecraft configuration; structural testing; bolted joint design.

ASTE561.name: ASTE 561: Human Factors of Spacecraft Operations (3.0 units)
ASTE561.desc: Engineering fundamentals and experimental methods of human factors design and evaluation for spacecraft which incorporate human-in-the-loop control.

ASTE580.name: ASTE 580: Orbital Mechanics I (3.0 units)
ASTE580.desc: Physical principles; two-body and central force motion; trajectory correction maneuvers; position and velocity in conic orbits; Lambert's problem; celestial mechanics; orbital perturbations.

ASTE583.name: ASTE 583: Space Navigation: Principles and Practice (3.0 units)
ASTE583.desc: Statistical orbit determination: (weighted) least squares, batch and sequential (Kalman) processing, illustrative examples; online ephemeris generation: potentially hazardous asteroids, comets, satellites; launch: vehicles, payloads, staging. Graduate standing in engineering or science. Recommended preparation: ASTE 580

BME101.name: BME 101: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering (4.0 units)
BME101.desc: Historical development and survey of major areas comprising biomedical engineering: theoretical neurobiology and systems physiology, biomedical instrumentation, artificial organ and prosthetic devices, biomedical computer applications.

BME202.name: BME 202: Control and Communication in the Nervous System (4.0 units)
BME202.desc: Introduction to the structure and function of the nervous system for biomedical engineers. Modeling of neurophysiological processes at single neuron and systems levels.

BME308.name: Crosslist BME 308: Computer-Aided Design for Bio-Mechanical Systems (3.0 units)
BME308.desc: Concepts of computer-aided design in 2-dimensions and 3-dimensions. Creating advanced parts using extrusions, surfaces, and equation driven sketches. Forming assemblies, and sub-assemblies, for motion analysis

BME403.name: BME 403L: Physiological Systems (4.0 units)
BME403.desc: A thorough bioengineering treatment of the physiological properties of various mammalian organ systems: e.g., cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and musculoskeletal.

BME404.name: BME 404: Biomechanics (3.0 units)
BME404.desc: Mechanical properties of biological tissues and fluid transport in physiological systems: blood rheology; bi- viscoelastic solids and fluids; gas flow and mixing; prosthesis design.

BME405.name: BME 405L: Senior Projects: Measurements and Instrumentation (4.0 units)
BME405.desc: Application of instrumentation and measurement techniques to biomedical engineering projects involving measurement, replacement or augmentation of biomedical systems.

BME406.name: BME 406: Introduction to Bioengineering in Medicine (3.0 units)
BME406.desc: Bioengineering concepts and technologies applied to cancer diagnosis, drug discovery, immunotherapeutic development, and mechanistic research.

BME413.name: BME 413: Bioengineering Signals and Systems (4.0 units)
BME413.desc: Introduction to concepts relating to linear signals and systems theory, time and frequency domain analysis, and application of these concepts to problems in Biomedical Engineering.

BME423.name: BME 423: Statistical Methods in Biomedical Engineering (4.0 units)
