BME423.desc: Applications of parametric and nonparametric tests, analysis of variance, linear regression, time-series analysis, and autoregressive modeling, with biomedical applications to statistical analysis of biomedical data.

BME425.name: BME 425: Basics of Biomedical Imaging (3.0 units)
BME425.desc: Engineering, Clinical applications and Modern Physics concepts underlying X-ray Imaging, Computed Tomography (CT), Nuclear Medicine, Positron Emission Tomography, Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), Ultrasound Imaging.

BME451.name: BME 451: Fundamentals of Biomedical Microdevices (3.0 units)
BME451.desc: Introduction to biomedical devices with emphasis on microtechnologies and biomedical microelectromechanical systems (bioMEMS). Principles for measurement of small-scale biological phenomena and clinical applications. Recommended preparation: basic biology and electronics

BME452.name: BME 452: Introduction to Biomimetic Neural Engineering (3.0 units)
BME452.desc: Engineering principles, biology, technological challenges and state-of-the-art developments in the design of implantable biomimetic microelectronic devices that interface with the nervous system. Recommended preparation: basic biology and electronics

BME502.name: BME 502: Advanced Studies of the Nervous System (4.0 units)
BME502.desc: Advanced topics on the structure and function of the nervous system examined from the viewpoint of computational systems science. Duplicates credit in BME 512.

BME505A.name: BME 505aL: Laboratory Projects in Biomedical Engineering (4.0 units)
BME505A.desc: Integration of biomedical science, engineering principles and state-of-the-art technology for the study of selected physiological systems in the laboratory setting. Laboratory.

BME513.name: BME 513: Signal and Systems Analysis (3.0 units)
BME513.desc: Classification; representation; statistical analysis; orthogonal expansions; least-squares estimation; harmonic analysis; Fourier, Laplace, and Z transforms; the linear system; filtering; modeling and simulation; linear control theory.

BME527.name: BME 527: Integration of Medical Imaging Systems (3.0 units)
BME527.desc: Medical imaging quality, compression, data standards, workflow analysis and protocols, broadband networks, image security, fault tolerance, picture archive communication system (PACS), image database and backup.

BME559.name: BME 559: Nanomedicine and Drug Delivery (3.0 units)
BME559.desc: Drug delivery and nanoengineered materials; cutting-edge nanoparticle-based therapy; imaging and tissue engineering; Nanotoxicology and regulatory landscape.

BME566A.name: BME 566a: Topics in Health, Technology and Engineering (2.0 units)
BME566A.desc: Interdisciplinary approach to impart the skills, knowledge and familiarity with stages of collaborative projects related to medical device and methods innovation in healthcare settings. Open only to Health, Technology and Engineering majors.

BME566C.name: BME 566c: Topics in Health, Technology and Engineering (2.0 units)
BME566C.desc: Interdisciplinary approach to impart the skills, knowledge and familiarity with stages of collaborative projects related to medical device and methods innovation in healthcare settings.

BME567A.name: BME 567a: Case Studies in Health, Technology and Engineering (1.0 unit)
BME567A.desc: Learning from cases illustrating paths from healthcare problems to solutions. Faculty, students and invited guests will provide examples of both successful and unsuccessful innovation attempts. Open only to Health, Technology and Engineering students. Concurrent enrollment: BME 566c.

BME620.name: BME 620L: Applied Electrophysiology (4.0 units)
BME620.desc: The theoretical basis and applied design principles for medical devices and instrumentation that interact with electrically excitable tissues of the body.

CHE120.name: CHE 120: Introduction to Chemical Engineering (4.0 units)
CHE120.desc: Problem-solving techniques in chemical engineering, including an introduction to engineering problem analysis, mass balances, and energy balances.

CHE305.name: CHE 305: Numerical and Statistical Analysis for Chemical Engineers (4.0 units)
CHE305.desc: Introduction to numerical algorithms, computational tools, principles of probability and statistics, and their application to chemical engineering problems.

CHE330.name: CHE 330: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics (4.0 units)
CHE330.desc: Basic laws, energy and entropy balances. Multi-component phase behavior. Physical and chemical equilibria. Energy conversion and equilibrium separation processes, estimation and use of property data.

CHE350.name: CHE 350: Introduction to Separation Processes (4.0 units)
CHE350.desc: Introduction to the design of chemical separation processes based on the principles of phase equilibrium, material balance and energy balance.

CHE391.name: CHE 391L: Introduction to Nanotechnology Research (2.0 units)
CHE391.desc: Planning and execution of an experiment, and presentation of findings through oral presentations and a written report.Application of the scientific method learned through immersion in a lab environment. Graded C/NC.

CHE444A.name: CHE 444aL: Chemical Engineering Laboratory (2.0 units)
CHE444A.desc: Conduct experiments and analyze data to generate results used to solve chemical engineering problems. Communicate results, data, and solutions in written reports and oral presentations.

CHE444B.name: CHE 444bL: Chemical Engineering Laboratory (2.0 units)
CHE444B.desc: Conduct experiments and analyze data to generate results used to solve chemical engineering problems. Communicate results, data, and solutions in written reports and oral presentations.

CHE447.name: CHE 447: Heat and Mass Transfer in Chemical Engineering Processes (4.0 units)
CHE447.desc: Differential and macroscopic equations of heat transfer; molecular and continuum approaches to diffusion and convection in fluids; simultaneous heat, mass and momentum transfer.

CHE450.name: CHE 450: Sustainable Energy (4.0 units)
CHE450.desc: Overview of sustainable energy, with emphasis on quantitative approaches to evaluate sustainability and examination of renewable sources of energy from the perspective of sustainability.

CHE460.name: CHE 460L: Chemical Process Dynamics and Control (4.0 units)
CHE460.desc: Dynamic analysis and automation of chemical processes using closed loop control schemes. Control schemes are analyzed, simulated and implemented in the laboratory.

CHE461.name: Crosslist CHE 461: Formation Data Sensing with Well Logs (4.0 units)
CHE461.desc: Measurement theory and petroleum/geothermal applications of electrical, radioactive, acoustic, and production logging tools. Estimation of rock porosity, water saturation, permeability, shale content, gas flow rate.

CHE463.name: Crosslist CHE 463L: Introduction to Transport Processes in Porous Media (4.0 units)
CHE463.desc: Fundamentals of flow and transport in porous materials including: Properties of porous rocks, capillarity effect, single- and multiphase flow, diffusion and dispersion in miscible displacements.

CHE465.name: Crosslist CHE 465L: Drilling Technology and Subsurface Methods (3.0 units)
CHE465.desc: Theory and practice in drilling technology; mechanical properties of reservoir rocks; well completion; acidizing and fracturing, oilproduction gechnology. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 3 hours

CHE487.name: CHE 487: Nanotechnology and Nanoscale Engineering through Chemical Pr (4.0 units)
CHE487.desc: Properties and processing of nanomaterials including polymeric, metallic, and ceramic nanoparticles, composites, colloids, and surfactant self-assembly for templated nanomaterial production.

CHE491.name: CHE 491: Nanotechnology Research for Undergraduates (2.0 units, max 4)
CHE491.desc: Independent research in nanotechnology. Research project selected by the student in close consultation with a research advisor. Prerequisite: CHE 391L. Open only to juniors and seniors.

CHE501.name: CHE 501: Modeling and Analysis of Chemical Engineering Systems (3.0 units)
CHE501.desc: Application of mathematics to problems in chemical engineering; mathematical modeling, differential and integral equations, linear systems analysis and stability, asymptotic and numerical methods. Recommended preparation: 445, MATH 245

CHE510.name: CHE 510: Energy and Process Efficiency (3.0 units)
CHE510.desc: Management and engineering strategies utilized to improve energy efficiency. Open only to master and doctoral students. Duplicates credit in AME 577.

CHE540.name: CHE 540: Viscous Flow (3.0 units)
CHE540.desc: Fluid mechanical problem of interest to chemical engineers involving laminar flows of incompressible fluids, viscous-dominated creeping flows, and motion of bubbles and drops.

CHE550A.name: CHE 550a: Seminars in Chemical Engineering (0.0 units)
CHE550A.desc: Seminars to cover recent developments in the field of chemical engineering given by invited speakers. Master's students must register for 2 semesters; Ph.D. students must register for 4 semesters. Graded IP/CR/NC. Recommended preparation: graduate standing

CHE550B.name: CHE 550b: Seminars in Chemical Engineering (1.0 units, max 2)
CHE550B.desc: Seminars to cover recent developments in the field of chemical engineering given by invited speakers. Master's students must register for 2 semesters; Ph.D. students must register for 4 semesters. Graded IP/CR/NC. Recommended preparation: graduate standing

CE106.name: CE 106: Introduction to Civil Engineering (2.0 units)
CE106.desc: Introduction to the civil engineering discipline, subdisciplines, technology and problem solving; technical report writing; contemporary civil engineering topics; engineering ethics.

CE110.name: CE 110: Introduction to Environmental Engineering (2.0 units)
CE110.desc: Basic concepts of environmental engineering including topics of water, land, energy, air, climate, resource management, human society and professional development.

CE205.name: CE 205: Statics (2.0 units)
CE205.desc: Statics of particles and rigid bodies; equivalent force systems; distributed forces; applications to trusses, frames, machines, beams, and cables; friction; moments of inertia.

CE210.name: CE 210L: Introduction to Environmental Engineering Microbiology (3.0 units)
CE210.desc: Principles of environmental microbiology; waterborne pathogens; microorganisms and air pollution; microorganisms in soil; water pollution microbiology; bioremediation and biotechnology. Recommended preparation: CE 106 or CE 110.

CE215.name: CE 215: Statics and Dynamics (4.0 units)
CE215.desc: Statics, kinematics and kinetics of systems of particles and rigid bodies; equivalent force systems; distributed forces and applications; moments of inertia, momentum, energy; vibrations; Eulers equations.

CE309.name: CE 309: Fluid Mechanics (4.0 units)
CE309.desc: Fluid statics; relative velocity field; total acceleration; divergence theorem; conservation of mass, energy, and momentum applied to engineering problems in laminar and turbulent flow.

CE334.name: CE 334L: Mechanical Behavior of Materials (4.0 units)
CE334.desc: Basic material science, atomic bonding, crystalline structures, structural and mechanical behavior and characterization of metals, concrete, wood, composites and asphalt.

CE358.name: CE 358L: Elementary Theory of Structures (4.0 units)
CE358.desc: Deformations and deflections of elastic systems; statically indeterminate beams, arches, and frames; secondary stresses; computer analysis of simple structural systems.

CE453.name: CE 453: Water Quality Science and Engineering (4.0 units)
CE453.desc: Water quality criteria and fundamentals of acceptability; processes employed in treatment of water and wastewater; water reclamation and reuse; sustainability in water and wastewater systems.

CE456.name: CE 456: Structural Design I (4.0 units)
CE456.desc: Structural design processes for wood, steel, concrete, and masonry structural beams, columns, and connections; determination of structural loads; framing systems; and applications of structural mechanics to the design process.

CE459.name: CE 459: Introduction to Structural Dynamics (2.0 units)
CE459.desc: Response of single and multiple degree of freedom systems to dynamic excitation; structural modeling and approximate solutions; introduction to earthquake resistant design.

CE460.name: CE 460: Construction Engineering (4.0 units)
CE460.desc: Introduction to the construction processes; estimating and bidding, construction administration, planning and scheduling, equipment and methods, labor relations, cost control systems, safety and ethics.

CE469.name: CE 469: Sustainable Design and Construction (2.0 units)
CE469.desc: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED); green building strategies; carbon footprinting; calculating the embodied energy of building materials; cyclical processes in design and construction.

CE476.name: CE 476: Design of Hydraulic Systems (4.0 units)
CE476.desc: Design of pressurized and free surface hydraulic systems, piping networks, surge suppression, pumps, turbines, submarine outfalls, water wave interactions with marine structures, breakwater design.

CE478.name: CE 478: Timber and Masonry Design (3.0 units)
CE478.desc: Characteristics and properties of wood; beams, columns, trusses, connectors, and diaphragms. Properties of masonry, working stress and strength design, seismic design requirements. Prerequisite: CE 207 and CE 225.

CE482.name: CE 482: Subsurface Foundation Design (4.0 units)
CE482.desc: Site exploration and characterization; analysis and design of structural foundations, including spread footings, mats, piles and drilled shafts; retaining wall and braced excavation design.

CE484.name: CE 484: Water Treatment Design (3.0 units)
CE484.desc: Predesign studies, precipitation softening, coagulation and flocculation, sedimentation, filtration, sludge handling, chlorination, chloramination, ozonation; plant hydraulics, flow measurement, pumps, instrumentation and control, tertiary treatment. Prerequisite: CE-451.

CE485.name: CE 485: Water Treatment Design (4.0 units)
CE485.desc: Engineering design of unit operations and unit processes for municipal wastewater treatment, including preliminary, primary, secondary, tertiary, and advanced treatments; disinfection; sludge treatment; sidestream treatment.

CE501.name: CE 501: Construction Practices (4.0 units)
CE501.desc: Systems, processes, and constraints governing the initiation, direction, engineering, and delivery of major construction projects. Professional construction management, responsibilities, and practice.

CE502.name: CE 502: Construction Business (4.0 units)
CE502.desc: Fundamental accounting principles, financial analysis and financial control, strategic management, and a review of alternative project delivery methods.

CE505.name: CE 505: Data Management for Civil and Environmental Engineering (3.0 units)
CE505.desc: The basics of databases and database management systems as applied to engineering problems. Introduction to data mining concepts, techniques, and knowledge discovery in database principles.

CE506.name: CE 506: Heavy Construction Estimating (3.0 units)
CE506.desc: Methods engineering, work analysis and pricing for route construction. Grading, draining, paving, haul economy, plant-materials production, pipeline and bridge building.

CE507.name: CE 507: Mechanics of Solids I (3.0 units)
CE507.desc: Analysis of stress and strain; constitutive equations for elastic materials; plane stress and strain; torsion; introduction to plates and shells; energy methods.

CE516.name: CE 516: Geohydrology (3.0 units)
CE516.desc: Principles of groundwater motion; acquifer characteristics, prospecting, practical engineering problems, well design, maintenance and rehabilitation; hydrodynamic dispersion, field testing essentials and procedures, groundwater quality, artificial recharge.

CE526.name: CE 526: Engineering Mathematical Methods (3.0 units)
CE526.desc: Engineering problems discussed on a physical basis with solutions via mathematical tools: Fourier series; Fourier and Laplace transforms; partial differential equations, wave and Laplace equations. Duplicates credit in CE 525b. Recommended preparation: undergraduate multivariable calculus and ordinary differential equations.

CE527.name: Crosslist CE 527: Climate Change and Atmospheric Aerosols (4.0 units)
CE527.desc: Climate change; climate science fundamentals; Earth's energy balance and atmosphere; greenhouse gas dynamics; fundamentals of airborne particles; climate-aerosol interactions; particle-radiation and particle-cloud interactions.

CE529A.name: CE 529a: Finite Element Analysis (3.0 units)
CE529A.desc: Basic concepts; stiffness method; variational methods; displacement method; isoparametric formulation; plane stress and strain; plates and shells; dynamics; stability; nonlinear analysis, heat transfer; computer applications.

CE535.name: CE 535: Earthquake Engineering: Strong Motion Studies (3.0 units)
CE535.desc: Earthquake source mechanisms; wave propagation, scattering, diffraction and amplification; empirical scaling of strong ground motion; seismic hazard analysis for earthquake resistant design codes and mapping. Duplicates credit in former CE 535a.

CE541A.name: CE 541a: Dynamics of Structures (3.0 units)
CE541A.desc: Forced vibrations of discrete MDOF systems; modal analysis; energy methods; analytical dynamics; vibration of continuous systems; wave propagation; computational techniques; application of commercial software tools.

CE546.name: CE 546: Structural Mechanics of Composite Materials (3.0 units)
CE546.desc: Applications and manufacturing of composites: anisotropic materials; laminated composite plates and shells; buckling and dynamics; strength and failure; intelaminar stresses; delamination; thermal properties; design considerations.

CE556.name: CE 556: Project Controls-Budgeting and Estimating (3.0 units)
CE556.desc: Fundamental principles and practices of cost estimating, budgeting, and cost control of construction projects. Case studies and software exercises based on project data.

CE564.name: CE 564: Construction Planning and Preconstruction (4.0 units)
CE564.desc: The steps and processes for the planning and pre-construction phases of a project using tools and technologies for budgeting, scheduling and planning.

CE569.name: CE 569: Project Controls (4.0 units)
CE569.desc: Project controls principles including costs and schedules, cost engineering concepts, schedule development, status evaluation, progress monitoring and responses to variances and changes.

CE570.name: CE 570: Building Information Modeling for Collaborative Construction (3.0 units)
CE570.desc: Multidisciplinary and geographically distributed virtual project teams used to simulate engineering and construction problems for projects selected in collaboration with industry partners. Recommended preparation:CE-556, CE-566.

CE573.name: CE 573: Advanced Technologies in AEC Practices (4.0 units)
CE573.desc: Data-centric engineering paradigms, modeling and simulation technologies; applications for Architecture, Engineering and Construction (AEC) projects or challenges.

CE574.name: CE 574: Construction Means and Methods (4.0 units)
CE574.desc: Job site logistics, field management, means and methods as they pertain to the builder, with an emphasis on constructability, productivity and schedule impacts for building construction.

CE579.name: CE 579: Introduction to Transportation Planning Law (2.0 units)
CE579.desc: Federal and state statutory and regulatory requirements affecting California transportation systems, including transportation planning and funding law; and government contracting, environmental and civil rights requirements.

CE584.name: CE 584: Intelligent Transportation Systems (4.0 units)
CE584.desc: Fundamentals of intelligent transportation systems, including automated vehicle technology and applications, communication systems, advanced transportation management systems, policy issues, transportation network services and smart cities.

CE585.name: CE 585: Traffic Engineering and Control (3.0 units)
CE585.desc: Conceptual engineering geometric design, installation, and calibration of vehicular storage and traffic controls; safe flow optimization of vehicles on various thoroughfares. Recommended preparation: CE 471.

CE634.name: Crosslist CE 634: Institutional and Policy Issues in Transportation (4.0 units)
CE634.desc: Analysis of policies relating to transportation alternatives; institutional environment and background; federal, state, regional, and local agency responsibilities and interactions.

CSCI100.name: CSCI 100xg: Explorations in Computing (4.0 units)
CSCI100.desc: A behind-the-scenes overview of the computational/algorithmic principles that form the basis of today's digital society. Exploration areas include social media, web search, videogames and location-based services.

CSCI103.name: CSCI 103L: Introduction to Programming (4.0 units)
CSCI103.desc: Basic datatypes, assignments, control statements (if, switch, for, while), input/output (printf, scanf, cin, cout), functions, arrays, structures, recursion, dynamic memory, file handling. Programming in C/C++.

CSCI104.name: CSCI 104L: Data Structures and Object Oriented Design (4.0 units)
CSCI104.desc: Introduces the student to standard data structures (linear structures such as linked lists, (balanced) trees, priority queues, and hashtables), using the C++ programming language.Prerequisite: CSCI 103. Corequisite: CSCI 170.

CSCI170.name: CSCI 170: Discrete Methods in Computer Science (4.0 units)
CSCI170.desc: Sets, functions, series. Big-O notation and algorithm analysis. Propositional and first-order logic. Counting and discrete probability. Graphs and basic graph algorithms. Basic number theory.

CSCI201.name: CSCI 201: Principles of Software Development (4.0 units)
CSCI201.desc: Object-oriented paradigm for programming-in-the-large in Java; writing sophisticated concurrent applications with animation and graphic user interfaces; using professional tools on team project. Prerequisite: CSCI 104L.

CSCI270.name: CSCI 270: Introduction to Algorithms and Theory of Computing (4.0 units)
CSCI270.desc: Algorithm analysis. Greedy algorithms, divide and conquer, dynamic programming, graph algorithms. NP-completeness and basic recursion theory and undecidability. Sorting lower bounds. Number-theory based cryptography.

CSCI280.name: Crosslist CSCI 280: Video Game Production (4.0 units)
CSCI280.desc: History of video games; overview of game genres; phases of video game development (concept, preproduction, production, post-production); roles of artists, programmers, designers, and producers.

CSCI310.name: CSCI 310: Software Engineering (4.0 units)
CSCI310.desc: Introduction to the software engineering process and software lifecycle. Covers project management, requirements, architecture, design, implementation, testing, and maintenance phase activities in team based projects. Prerequisites: CSCI 201. Duplicates credit in former CSCI 377.

CSCI350.name: CSCI 350: Introduction to Operating Systems (4.0 units)
CSCI350.desc: Basic issues in concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization scheduling, memory management, protection and access control, inter-process communication, and structured design. Laboratory experiences with Unix-like operating system. Duplicates credit in CSCI 402.

CSCI353.name: CSCI 353: Introduction to Internetworking (4.0 units)
CSCI353.desc: Global Internet: design principles, layering, protocol design/analysis.Networked applications, Internet structure/architecture,Protocols for transport/congestion control, network layer/routing,link layer/MAC. Network security. Prerequisites: CSCI 201. Recommended preparation: Familiarity with C and C++.Duplicates credit in EE 450.

CSCI356.name: CSCI 356: Introduction to Computer Systems (4.0 units)
CSCI356.desc: Computer organization; entity abstraction and representation; program execution; code optimization; memory usage; exception handling; processing control; computer performance; hands-on work done in C and assembly.

CSCI360.name: CSCI 360: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence (4.0 units)
CSCI360.desc: Concepts and algorithms underlying the understanding and construction of intelligent systems. Agents, problem solving, search, representation, reasoning, planning, machine learning. Prerequisites: CSCI 104 and CSCI 170. Duplicates credit in former CSCI 460.

CSCI368.name: Crosslist CSCI 368: Programming Graphical User Interfaces (4.0 units)
CSCI368.desc: Programming applications with dynamic graphical user interfaces. Topics include events, controls, resources, data bindings, styles and user experience.

CSCI380.name: Crosslist CSCI 380: Video Game Programming (4.0 units)
CSCI380.desc: Underlying concepts and principles required for programming video games (topics include vectors, transformations, 3-D math, geometric primitives, matrices). Prerequisite: CSCI-104 or ITP-365.

CSCI401.name: CSCI 401: Capstone: Design and Construction of Large Software Systems (4.0 units, max 8)
CSCI401.desc: Group project with an outside stakeholder to develop real-world software solutions to large-scale problems. Topics include software engineering, professional preparation, and recent computer science research. Duplicates credit in CSCI 477a and CSCI 477b.

CSCI402.name: CSCI 402: Operating Systems (4.0 units)
CSCI402.desc: Concurrency, deadlock control, synchronization, process and thread scheduling, memory management, file systems, security and access control, communication and networking, distributed file systems, data management.

CSCI420.name: CSCI 420: Computer Graphics (4.0 units)
CSCI420.desc: Computer graphics, OpenGL, 2D and 3D transformations, Bzier splines, computer animation, rendering including ray tracing, shading and lighting, artistic rendering, virtual reality, visualization.

CSCI430.name: CSCI 430: Introduction to Computer and Network Security (4.0 units)
CSCI430.desc: A broad overview of security threats and defenses, security systems and functionalities, as well as current security practices. Includes homeworks and in-class exercises to provide practical experience working with such systems. Prerequisite: CSCI 201.

CSCI435.name: Crosslist CSCI 435: Professional C++ (4.0 units)
CSCI435.desc: Applications of advanced concepts in C++ including lambda expressions, templates, secure coding, parallel programming, writing performant code, CMake and continuous integration.

CSCI445.name: CSCI 445L: Introduction to Robotics (4.0 units)
CSCI445.desc: Designing, building and programming mobile robots; sensors, effectors, basic control theory, control architectures, some advanced topics, illustrations of state-of-the-art. Teamwork; final project tested in a robot contest. Junior standing or higher. Prerequisites: CSCI 103.

CSCI450.name: Crosslist CSCI 450: Introduction to Computer Networks (4.0 units)
CSCI450.desc: Network architectures; layered protocols, network service interface; local, wide area, wireless networks; Internet protocols; link protocols; addressing; routing; flow control; software defined network; multimedia networks.

CSCI452.name: Crosslist CSCI 452: Parallel and Distributed Computation (4.0 units)
CSCI452.desc: Introduction to parallel programming techniques, models and optimization strategies; Application mapping to multi-core, accelerator, GPU and cloud platforms; High Performance Computing and Data Science applications.

CSCI454.name: Crosslist CSCI 454L: Introduction to System-on-Chip (4.0 units)
CSCI454.desc: Design flow, tools, and issues related to System/Network-on-Chip (S/Noc) design for real-time embedded systems with applications in mobile, cloud, aerospace, and medical electronics. Prerequisite: EE 354.

CSCI455.name: CSCI 455x: Introduction to Programming Systems Design (4.0 units)
CSCI455.desc: Intensive introduction to programming principles, discrete mathematics for computing, software design and software engineering concepts. Not available for credit to computer sciencemajors, graduate or undergraduate.

CSCI457.name: Crosslist CSCI 457: Computer Systems Organization (4.0 units)
CSCI457.desc: Register Transfer level machine organization; performance; arithmetic; pipelined processors; exceptions, out-of-order and speculative execution, cache, virtual memory, multi-core multi-threaded processors, cache coherence.

CSCI458.name: Crosslist CSCI 458: Numerical Methods (4.0 units)
CSCI458.desc: Rounding errors in digital computation; solution of linear algebraic systems; Newton's method for nonlinear systems; matrix eigenvalues; polynomial approximation; numerical integration; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

CSCI467.name: CSCI 467: Introduction to Machine Learning (4.0 units)
CSCI467.desc: Methods for building intelligent and adaptive systems from statistical analyses; theoretical understanding of such methods and the computational implications.

CSCI476.name: CSCI 476: Cryptography: Secure Communication and Computation (4.0 units)
CSCI476.desc: Introduction to modern Cryptography; Mathematical/algorithmic studies of methods for protecting information in computer and communication systems: Public-Key Cryptosystems, zero-knowledge proofs, data privacy. Prerequisites: CSCI 270.

CSCI487.name: Crosslist CSCI 487: Programming Game Engines (4.0 units)
CSCI487.desc: Techniques for building the core components of a game engine; 2-D/3-D graphics, collision detection, artificial intelligence algorithms, shading, programming input devices. Prerequisite: ITP-380.

CSCI495.name: Crosslist CSCI 495: Senior Project (2.0 units)
CSCI495.desc: An original project will be constructed applying computer technology (in either hardware or software) to produce a result useful in the physics classroom or laboratory.

CSCI505A.name: Crosslist CSCI 505a: Applied Probability (3.0 units)
CSCI505A.desc: Populations, permutations, combinations, random variables, distribution and density functions, conditional probability and expectation,; binomial, poisson, and normal distributions; laws of large numbers, central limit theorem. Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor.

CSCI510.name: CSCI 510: Software Management and Economics (4.0 units)
CSCI510.desc: Theories of management and their application to software projects. Economic analysis of software products and processes. Software cost and schedule estimation, planning and control.

CSCI526.name: CSCI 526: Advanced Mobile Devices and Game Consoles (4.0 units)
CSCI526.desc: Explore the complex engineering process required to design and build a real-time graphics engine to support physical realism on mobile devices. Recommended preparation: CSCI 420 or CSCI 580 or an equivalent course in graphics.

CSCI529A.name: CSCI 529a: Advanced Game Projects (4.0 units)
CSCI529A.desc: Team projects intended to address the multifaceted technical and creative challenges that are inherent to comprehensive game development. Recommended preparation: CSCI 522 or CTIN 488.

CSCI530.name: CSCI 530: Security Systems (4.0 units)
CSCI530.desc: Protecting computer networks and systems using cryptography, authentication, authorization, intrusion detection and response. Includes lab to provide practical experience working with such systems.

CSCI536.name: Crosslist CSCI 536: Linear Programming and Extensions (3.0 units)
CSCI536.desc: Linear programming models for resource allocation; simplex and revised simplex methods; duality; sensitivity; transportation problems; selected extensions to large scale, multiobjective, and special structured models.

CSCI537.name: Crosslist CSCI 537: Foundations of Data Management (4.0 units)
CSCI537.desc: Function and design of modern storage systems, including cloud; data management techniques; data modeling; network attached storage, clusters and data centers; relational databases; the map-reduce paradigm.

CSCI544.name: CSCI 544: Applied Natural Language Processing (4.0 units)
CSCI544.desc: Introduction to key components of human language technologies, including: information extraction, sentiment analysis, question answering, machine translation.

CSCI545.name: CSCI 545: Robotics (4.0 units)
CSCI545.desc: Fundamental skills for modeling and controlling of dynamic systems for robotic applications and graphics animations; control theory; kinematics; dynamics; sensor processing; real-time operating systems; robot labs. Recommended preparation: Basic knowledge in linear algebra (matrices and vectors), calculus, programming in C/C++ or any another language or permission of the instructor.

CSCI556.name: CSCI 556: Introduction to Cryptography (4.0 units)
CSCI556.desc: Modern secret codes. Public key cryptosystems of Rivest- Shamir-Adleman, Diffie-Hellman and others. The underlying number theory and computational complexity theory.

CSCI557.name: Crosslist CSCI 557: Computer Systems Architecture (4.0 units)
CSCI557.desc: Computer architecture from a design perspective: Pipelined processors, speculative execution, VLIW, vector processors, GPU/GPGPU, memory technology and systems, interconnection networks, shared-memory and message-passing multiprocessors, chip multiprocessors.

CSCI560.name: Crosslist CSCI 560: Information Visualization (4.0 units)
CSCI560.desc: Graphical depictions of data for communication, analysis, and decision support. Cognitive processing and perception of visual data and visualizations. Designing effective visualizations. Implementing interactive visualizations.

CSCI566.name: CSCI 566: Deep Learning and Its Applications (4.0 units)
CSCI566.desc: Deep learning research in computer vision, natural language processing and robotics; neural networks; deep learning algorithms, tools and software.

CSCI567.name: CSCI 567: Machine Learning (4.0 units)
CSCI567.desc: Statistical methods for building intelligent and adaptive systems that improve performance from experiences; Focus on theoretical understanding of these methods and their computational implications. Recommended preparation: Undergraduate level training or coursework in linear algebra, multivariate calculus, basic probability and statistics; an undergraduate level course in Artificial Intelligence may be helpful but is not required.

CSCI570.name: CSCI 570: Analysis of Algorithms (4.0 units)
CSCI570.desc: Explores fundamental techniques such as recursion, Fourier transform ordering, dynamic programming for efficient algorithm construction. Examples include arithmetic, algebraic, graph, pattern matching, sorting, searching algorithms.

CSCI571.name: CSCI 571: Web Technologies (4.0 units)
CSCI571.desc: Advanced study of programming languages with application to the Web. Languages for client-side and server-side processing. Examples taken from: HTML, Java, JavaScript, Perl, XML and others. Recommended preparation: knowledge of at least two programming languages

CSCI576.name: CSCI 576: Multimedia Systems Design (4.0 units)
CSCI576.desc: End-to-end multimedia systems - content creation, compression, distribution using modern standards, DRM solutions, Digital-Cinema pipeline, multimedia classification, virtual-augmented reality, natural-language multimedia queries, multimodal media analysis, stereoscopic-holographic technologies.

CSCI577A.name: CSCI 577a: Software Engineering (4.0 units)
CSCI577A.desc: A: Software life-cycle processes; planning considerations for product definition, development, test, implemetation, maintenance. Team project. Graduate standing.

CSCI578.name: CSCI 578: Software Architectures (4.0 units)
CSCI578.desc: Study of concepts, principles and scope of software system architectures, including architectural styles, languages, connectors, middleware, dynamism, analysis, testing and domain-specific approaches.

CSCI580.name: CSCI 580: 3-D Graphics and Rendering (4.0 units)
CSCI580.desc: Course outlines the process of creating images from 3D models. Includes transformations, shading, lighting, rastorization, texturing, and other topics.

CSCI585.name: CSCI 585: Database Systems (4.0 units)
CSCI585.desc: Database system architecture; conceptual database models; semantic, object-oriented, logic-based, and relational databases; user and program interfaces; database system implementation; integrity, security, concurrency and recovery. Recommended preparation: Knowledge of relational databases, SQL, relational algebra and physical database design is required. Open only to graduate students.

CSCI587.name: CSCI 587: Geospatial Information Management (4.0 units)
CSCI587.desc: Techniques to efficiently store, manipulate, index and query geospatial information in support of real-world geographical and decision-making applications.

CSCI591.name: CSCI 591: Computer Science Research Colloquium (1.0 units, max 2)
CSCI591.desc: Exploration and critical assessment of research activities in computer science. Course will serve as a forum for current research presentations from academia and industry. Graded CR/NC.

CSCI593.name: Crosslist CSCI 593: Mathematical Foundations for System Design: Modeling, Analys (4.0 units)
CSCI593.desc: Fundamental techniques underlying the methodologies for system design, from integrated circuits to cyber-physical systems. Design flows, fundamental classes of models, and verification and synthesis techniques.

CSCI646.name: CSCI 646: Coordinated Mobile Robotics (4.0 units)
CSCI646.desc: State-of-the-art techniques for coordinating robot teams. Distributed approaches; task allocation; control and stability; network topology; coverage and monitoring; caging; bio-inspired approaches; persistence; probabilistic methods. Recommended preparation: Solid background in linear algebra, programming and algorithm analysis skills. Open only to Computer Science doctoral students.

CSCI651.name: CSCI 651: Advanced Computer Networking (4.0 units)
CSCI651.desc: Computer communication protocols and systems, including classic and contemporary literature. The emphasis is on conceptual issues in the design and implementation of computer internetworks.

CSCI653.name: CSCI 653: High Performance Computing and Simulations (4.0 units)
CSCI653.desc: Advanced high-performance computer simulation techniques; multiscale deterministic and stochastic simulation algorithms on parallel and distributed computing platforms; immersive and interactive visualization of simulation data. Prerequisite: CSCI 596.

CSCI658.name: Crosslist CSCI 658: Diagnosis and Design of Reliable Digital Systems (3.0 units)
CSCI658.desc: Fault models; test generation; fault simulation; self-checking and self-testing circuits; design for testability; fault tolerant design techniques; case studies.

CSCI662.name: CSCI 662: Advanced Natural Language Processing (4.0 units)
CSCI662.desc: Computational models of natural language. Formalisms for describing structures of human language, and algorithms for learning language structures from data. Recommended preparation: Proficiency in programming, algorithms and data structures, discrete math, probability theory, and calculus. Open only to doctoral students. (Duplicates credit in former CSCI 562)

CSCI670.name: CSCI 670: Advanced Analysis of Algorithms (4.0 units)
CSCI670.desc: Fundamental techniques for design and analysis of algorithms. Dynamic programming; network flows; theory of NP-completeness; linear programming; approximation, randomized, and online algorithms; basic cryptography. Prerequisite: CSCI 570. Recommended preparation: familiarity with algorithms and discrete mathematics. Open only to doctoral students.

CSCI675.name: CSCI 675: Convex and Combinatorial Optimization (4.0 units)
CSCI675.desc: Topics include: Convex sets and functions; convex optimization problems; geometric and Lagrangian duality; simplex algorithm; ellipsoid algorithm and its implications; matroid theory; submodular optimization.

CSCI677.name: CSCI 677: Advanced Computer Vision (4.0 units)
CSCI677.desc: Fundamental issues in computer vision: theory, algorithms and applications. Image formation, image segmentation, inference and measurement of 3-D, motion analysis, object and activity recognition.

CSCI697.name: CSCI 697: Seminar in Computer Science Research (1.0 units, max 2)
CSCI697.desc: Introduction of Ph.D. students to the broad range of computer science research. Two semesters registration required. Open to Computer Science doctoral students only. Graded CR/NC. Duplicates credit in former CSCI 597.

CSCI698.name: CSCI 698: Practicum in Teaching Computer Science (1.0 units, max 2)
CSCI698.desc: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching in Computer Science. Intended for teaching assistants for classes offered by the Computer Science department. Graded CR/NC. Open only to Computer Science doctoral students.

EE105.name: EE 105: Introduction to Electrical Engineering (4.0 units)
EE105.desc: Electrical engineering overview: communications, computers, circuits, components, signals, electromagnetics, microelectronics; data encoding and compression, USPS and UPC product codes, DVDs, semiconductor devices, and integrated circuits.

EE109.name: EE 109L: Introduction to Embedded Systems (4.0 units)
EE109.desc: Information representations, embedded programming, digital and serial I/O, analog-to-digital conversion, and interrupt mechanisms. Elementary analog, logic, and state-machine design.

EE155.name: EE 155L: Introduction to Computer Programming for Electrical Engineers (4.0 units)
EE155.desc: Introduction to solving engineering problems using computational methods. Survey of various programming languages and their strengths and weaknesses. Program structure, input/output, conditionals, loops, functions, arrays.

EE202.name: EE 202L: Linear Circuits (4.0 units)
EE202.desc: Lumped circuit elements; network equations; zero-input and zero-state responses; sinusoidal steady-state analysis; impedance;resonance; network functions; power concepts; transformers; Laplace transforms.

EE250.name: EE 250L: Distributed Systems for the Internet of Things (4.0 units)
EE250.desc: Introduction to hardware, operating systems, signal processing and control, network protocols, mobile applications, databases, cloud computing, machine learning, and security for the Internet of Things.

EE301.name: EE 301: Linear Systems (4.0 units)
EE301.desc: Representation and analysis of linear time-invariant systems primarily for the continuous time case. Convolution, Fourier series and transform, Laplace transform, controls and communications applications.

EE330.name: EE 330: Electromagnetics I (3.0 units)
EE330.desc: Basic static and dynamic electromagnetic field theory and applications; electrostatics, magnetostatics, Maxwell's equations, energy flow, plane waves incident on planar boundaries, transmission lines.

EE338.name: EE 338: Physical Electronics (4.0 units)
EE338.desc: Semiconductor device characteristics and applications. Physical models of electronic conduction in solids, p-n junctions, bipolar and field effect transistors and other solid-state devices.

EE354.name: EE 354L: Introduction to Digital Circuits (4.0 units)
EE354.desc: Digital system design and implementation; synchronous design of datapath and control; schematic/Verilog-based design, simulation, and implementation in Field Programmable Gate Arrays; timing analysis; semester-end project.

EE364.name: EE 364: Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (4.0 units)
EE364.desc: Introduction to concepts of randomness and uncertainty: probability, random variables, statistics. Applications to digital communications, signal processing, automatic control, computer engineering and computer science.

EE443.name: EE 443: Introduction to Power Systems (4.0 units)
EE443.desc: Components of power systems; analysis techniques in electrical power generation transmission and utilization; and environmental and economic considerations in system operations and planning.

EE444.name: EE 444: Power Systems Technology (4.0 units)
EE444.desc: Comprehensive assessment of the technical, environmental, and regulatory challenges that affect the future delivery and utilization of electric power. Case-study analysis.

EE445.name: Crosslist EE 445L: Introduction to Robotics (4.0 units)
EE445.desc: Designing, building and programming mobile robots; sensors, effectors, basic control theory, control architectures, some advanced topics, illustrations of state-of-the-art. Teamwork; final project tested in a robot contest. Junior standing or higher. Prerequisites: CSCI 103.

EE450.name: EE 450: Introduction to Computer Networks (4.0 units)
EE450.desc: Network architectures; layered protocols, network service interface; local, wide area, wireless networks; Internet protocols; link protocols; addressing; routing; flow control; software defined network; multimedia networks.

EE451.name: EE 451: Parallel and Distributed Computation (4.0 units)
EE451.desc: Introduction to parallel programming techniques, models and optimization strategies; Application mapping to multi-core, accelerator, GPU and cloud platforms; High Performance Computing and Data Science applications.

EE454.name: EE 454L: Introduction to System-on-Chip (4.0 units)
EE454.desc: Design flow, tools, and issues related to System/Network-on-Chip (S/Noc) design for real-time embedded systems with applications in mobile, cloud, aerospace, and medical electronics. Prerequisite: EE 354.

EE455.name: Crosslist EE 455x: Introduction to Programming Systems Design (4.0 units)
EE455.desc: Intensive introduction to programming principles, discrete mathematics for computing, software design and software engineering concepts. Not available for credit to computer sciencemajors, graduate or undergraduate.

EE457.name: EE 457: Computer Systems Organization (4.0 units)
EE457.desc: Register Transfer level machine organization; performance; arithmetic; pipelined processors; exceptions, out-of-order and speculative execution, cache, virtual memory, multi-core multi-threaded processors, cache coherence.

EE470.name: EE 470: Electromagnetics II (3.0 units)
EE470.desc: Dynamic field theory and elementary solutions to Maxwell's equations. Introduction to propagation and radiation of electromagnetic fields. Prerequisite: 330.

EE471.name: EE 471: Applied Quantum Mechanics for Engineers (4.0 units)
EE471.desc: Introductory quantum mechanics and applications. Schrodinger equation, atomic and molecular processes, time-dependent perturbation theory. Applications to lasers, solid-state demos and gaseous devices.

EE477.name: EE 477L: MOS VLSI Circuit Design (4.0 units)
EE477.desc: Analysis and design of digital MOS VLSI circuits including area, delay and power minimization. Laboratory assignments including design, layout, extraction, simulation and automatic synthesis.

EE479.name: EE 479: Analog Integrated Circuit Design (4.0 units)
EE479.desc: MOSFET and BJT operation and models; elementary amplifier configurations; biasing and references; frequency response; feedback; operational amplifiers. Prerequisite: EE 348.

EE482.name: EE 482: Linear Control Systems (3.0 units)
EE482.desc: Analysis of linear control systems; continuous and sampled-data systems, various stability criteria; frequency response and rootlocus compensation techniques. (Duplicates credit in AME 451)

EE483.name: EE 483: Introduction to Digital Signal Processing (4.0 units)
EE483.desc: Fundamentals of digital signal processing covering: discrete time linear systems, quantization, sampling, Z-transforms, Fourier transforms, FFTs and filter design.

EE500.name: EE 500: Neural Learning and Computational Intelligence (4.0 units)
EE500.desc: Computational intelligence techniques that include neural systems, deep learning, adaptive pattern classification, fuzzy function approximation, simulated annealing and evolutionary computing, and hybrid systems.

EE503.name: EE 503: Probability for Electrical and Computer Engineers (4.0 units)
EE503.desc: Rigorous coverage of probability, discrete and continuous random variables, functions of multiple random variables, covariance, correlation, random sequences, Markov chains, estimation, and introduction to statistics. Duplicates credit in former EE 464 and EE 465.

EE504.name: EE 504L: Solid State Processing and Integrated Circuits Laboratory (3.0 units)
EE504.desc: Laboratory oriented with lectures keyed to practical procedures and processes. Solid-state fabrication and analysis fundamentals; basic device construction techniques. Prerequisite: BSEE

EE506.name: EE 506: Semiconductor Physics (4.0 units)
EE506.desc: Semiconductor bonds, crystallography, band structure assumptions, group theory, band structure results, k.p. method, quantum wells, wires and dots, superlattices, amorphous, organic semiconductors, defects, statistics, surfaces.

EE508.name: EE 508: Nano-Fabrication Lithography (3.0 units)
EE508.desc: Physical basis of lithography methods for nano-scale devices. Photon-, electron-, and ion-based systems, advanced processes; resolution enhancement techniques; directed self assembly.

EE510.name: EE 510: Linear Algebra for Engineering (4.0 units)
EE510.desc: Introduction to linear algebra and matrix theory and their underlying concepts; applications to engineering problems; mathematically rigorous and foundational to other classes in communication, control, and signal processing.

EE511.name: EE 511: Simulation Methods for Stochastic Systems (1.0 unit)
EE511.desc: Project-oriented investigation of simulation methods used for the analysis and design of complex stochastic systems whose operation and performance are affected by random events. Corequisite: EE 503. Recommended preparation: MatLab programming experience.

EE512.name: EE 512: Stochastic Processes (3.0 units)
EE512.desc: Probability theory and stochastic processes, including renewal theory, Markov chains, Brownian motion, martingales, and stochastic calculus. Applications in communication networks, queuing theory and financial systems.

EE513.name: EE 513: Solid State Energy Devices (3.0 units)
EE513.desc: Design and operation of solar photovoltaic energy converters, thermovoltoic energy converters, thermoelectric energy converters, and solid state light emitters; their roles in renewal and conservation of energy. Recommended Preparation EE 338.

EE516.name: EE 516: High-Voltage DC Transmission Systems (4.0 units)
EE516.desc: AC/DC conversion processes, converter technologies, and design; harmonics, controls, and protection; AC/DC interactions and system performance; modeling, application, and installation; current-source versus voltage-source converters.

EE518.name: EE 518: Mathematics and Tools for Financial Engineering (4.0 units)
EE518.desc: Students will build a mathematical background for studying Financial Engineering. Emphasis is on analysis, proofs and examples. Mathworks Financial toolbox will be introduced.

EE520.name: EE 520: Introduction to Quantum Information Processing (3.0 units)
EE520.desc: Introduces the basics of quantum computation and quantum information theory: quantum bits and registers, unitary gates, algorithms, error correction, and quantum cryptography.

EE528.name: EE 528: Power Electronics (4.0 units)
EE528.desc: Fundamentals of switched-mode power converters operating under steadystate and transient conditions. Feedback control systems. Magnetic circuit design.

EE529.name: EE 529: Optics (4.0 units)
EE529.desc: Geometrical optics, electromagnetic wave propagation, reflection and refraction at interfaces, imaging with lenses and mirrors, optics of the eye, optical instruments (microscopes/telescopes/cameras), and polarization.

EE534.name: Crosslist EE 534: Materials Characterization (3.0 units)
EE534.desc: Characterization of solids by optical microscopy, electron microscopy, (TEM, SEM) and elemental and structural analysis (EPMA, ESCA, AES, SIMS, HEED, LEED, SED, etc.).

EE536A.name: EE 536a: Mixed-Signal Integrated Circuit Design (4.0 units)
EE536A.desc: a: MOSFET operation and models; elementary amplifier configurations; biasing and references; frequency response; noise; feedback; operational amplifiers; frequency compensation; non-linearity and mismatch; passive and active filters. Prerequisite: EE 448L or EE 479.

EE537.name: EE 537: Modern Solid-State Devices (4.0 units)
EE537.desc: Integrated-circuit technologies for mixed-signal communication and data systems. Constituent device models and their limitations. Contemporary research topics.

EE539.name: EE 539: Engineering Quantum Mechanics (4.0 units)
EE539.desc: Quantum mechanics for engineering majors who work with solid-state devices, quantum electronics, and photonics. Schroedinger equation, perturbation theory, electronic and optical processes.

EE542.name: EE 542: Internet and Cloud Computing (3.0 units)
EE542.desc: Principles and technologies of server clusters, virtualized datacenters, Grids/P2P, Internet clouds, social networks, Internet of Things (IoT), and their innovative applications. Recommended preparation: EE 450 or EE 457.

EE545.name: Crosslist EE 545: Robotics (4.0 units)
EE545.desc: Fundamental skills for modeling and controlling of dynamic systems for robotic applications and graphics animations; control theory; kinematics; dynamics; sensor processing; real-time operating systems; robot labs. Recommended preparation: Basic knowledge in linear algebra (matrices and vectors), calculus, programming in C/C++ or any another language or permission of the instructor.

EE546.name: EE 546: Mathematics of High-Dimensional Data (4.0 units)
EE546.desc: Modern developments in data representation/analysis, nonconvex optimization, high-dimensional probability, sketching, clustering, low-rank models, inverse problems, applications in imaging, machine learning, computer vision and neuroscience.

EE549.name: EE 549: Nanotechnology for Materials, Electronics, and Circuits (4.0 units)
EE549.desc: Nanotechnology for advanced nanomaterials, nanoelectronics devices, and circuits, including the rigorous treatment of electronic band structures of carbon nanotubes, graphene, and two-dimensional materials.

EE550.name: EE 550: Data Networks: Design and Analysis (4.0 units)
EE550.desc: Applications of stochastic modeling and optimization techniques to communication network design and analysis. Data link control; performance models; multi-access channels; routing and flow control.

EE551.name: EE 551: Principles of Radar (3.0 units)
EE551.desc: Signal propagation, reflections from targets; radar equation; detection of scintillating targets; resolution; ambiguity functions; clutter rejection; tracking radars. Prerequisites: EE 364 and EE 470.

EE555.name: EE 555: Broadband Network Architectures (3.0 units)
EE555.desc: Broadband network architectures and services, technologies for high-speed access and core networks, optical infrastructure for layered network architectures, high performance switch and router architectures. Prerequisites: EE 450 and EE-503.

EE556.name: EE 556: Stochastic Systems and Reinforcement Learning (4.0 units)
EE556.desc: Stochastic system models, Dynamic programming, Linear quadratic control, Kalman filtering and estimation, System identification, approximate dynamic programming methods, adaptive control, reinforcement and online learning.

EE557.name: EE 557: Computer Systems Architecture (4.0 units)
EE557.desc: Computer architecture from a design perspective: Pipelined processors, speculative execution, VLIW, vector processors, GPU/GPGPU, memory technology and systems, interconnection networks, shared-memory and message-passing multiprocessors, chip multiprocessors.

EE558.name: EE 558: Optical Fiber Communication Systems (3.0 units)
EE558.desc: State-of-the-art optical fiber communication system. Emphasis on optoelectronic-device and communication-systems issues necessary to provide high-speed and/or networked optical communications. Recommended preparation: EE 338; basic knowledge of optics, semiconductor, and communications concepts.

EE562.name: EE 562: Random Processes in Engineering (4.0 units)
EE562.desc: Random vectors, sequences, and functions. Linear transformations, second moment theory, spectral densities, narrowband processes, Gaussian processes, correlation detection, linear minimum mean square error estimation.

EE566.name: EE 566: Optical Information Processing (3.0 units)
EE566.desc: Coherent and incoherent optical transforming, imaging and two-dimensional information processing systems; optical image processing, spatial frequency response and filtering; optical and digital holography.

EE567.name: EE 567: Communication Systems (3.0 units)
EE567.desc: Analysis of communication systems operating from very low to optical frequencies. Comparison of modulation and detection methods. System components description. Optimum design of communication systems.

EE577A.name: EE 577a: VLSI System Design (3.0 units)
EE577A.desc: Integrated circuit fabrication; circuit simulation; basic device physics; simple device layout: structured chip design; timing; project chip; MOS logic; system design; silicon compilers.

EE577B.name: EE 577b: VLSI System Design (3.0 units)
EE577B.desc: VLSI design project; chip level design issues: power and clock distribution, packaging, I/O; design techniques; testability; chip fabrication and test.

EE581.name: EE 581: Mathematical Foundations for System Design: Modeling, Analys (4.0 units)
EE581.desc: Fundamental techniques underlying the methodologies for system design, from integrated circuits to cyber-physical systems. Design flows, fundamental classes of models, and verification and synthesis techniques.

EE585.name: EE 585: Linear System Theory (3.0 units)
EE585.desc: Analysis of linear dynamical systems by state-space techniques; controllability, observability, stability, passivity. Application of feedback control and network synthesis.

EE588.name: EE 588: Optimization for the Information and Data Sciences (4.0 units)
EE588.desc: Convex sets, functions, and optimization problems. Basic convex analysis and theory of convex programming. Novel, efficient first-order algorithms. Applications in the information and data sciences.

EE593.name: EE 593: Robust Multivariable Control (3.0 units)
EE593.desc: Sensitivity and complementary sensitivity matrices; uncertainty representation; singular values; Bode plots. Parameterization of internally stabilizing controllers. Algebraic Riccati Equations. Modern Wiener-Hopf and H-infinity designs.

EE597.name: EE 597: Wireless Networks (4.0 units)
EE597.desc: Introduction to wireless networking technologies; fundamental architectural and design principles used at all protocol layers; optimization, performance evaluation and implementation using mathematical analysis, simulations, and experiments.

EE598.name: EE 598: Electrical Engineering Research Seminar (1.0 units, max 2)
EE598.desc: Introduction to research in electrical engineering. Topics vary by semester. May be repeated for up to one unit of credit for MS students, two units of credit for PhD students. Open only to Masterâ€™s and Doctoral Students.

EE648.name: EE 648: Network Economics and Games (3.0 units)
EE648.desc: Economics of networks; Game theory, Mechanism design and auctions in networks; spectrum sharing mechanisms in communications; pricing of differentiated services; network security. Prerequisites: EE-450 and EE-503.

EE658.name: EE 658: Diagnosis and Design of Reliable Digital Systems (3.0 units)
EE658.desc: Fault models; test generation; fault simulation; self-checking and self-testing circuits; design for testability; fault tolerant design techniques; case studies.

EE660.name: EE 660: Machine Learning from Signals: Foundations and Methods (3.0 units)
EE660.desc: Supervised, semisupervised, and unsupervised machine learning; classification and regression. Model complexity, assessment, and selection; performance (error) on unseen data.

EE669.name: EE 669: Multimedia Data Compression (3.0 units)
EE669.desc: Lossless compression, audio/speech coding, vector quantization, fractal compression, JPEG and JPEG-2000, video compression techniques and MPEG standards, video transmission over wired and wireless networks. Recommended preparation: EE-503.

EE676.name: Crosslist EE 676: Advanced Computer Vision (4.0 units)
EE676.desc: Fundamental issues in computer vision: theory, algorithms and applications. Image formation, image segmentation, inference and measurement of 3-D, motion analysis, object and activity recognition.

ENE215.name: ENE 215: Energy Systems and Environmental Tradeoffs (4.0 units)
ENE215.desc: Energy fundamentals; critical issues facing energy extraction, cultivation, transformation, transportation, consumption and disposal; environmental impacts.

ENE527.name: ENE 527: Climate Change and Atmospheric Aerosols (4.0 units)
ENE527.desc: Climate change; climate science fundamentals; Earth's energy balance and atmosphere; greenhouse gas dynamics; fundamentals of airborne particles; climate-aerosol interactions; particle-radiation and particle-cloud interactions.

ENE590.name: ENE 590: Directed Research (1.0-12.0 units)
ENE590.desc: . Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

ENGR100A.name: ENGR 100a: Engineering Honors Colloquium (1.0 unit)
ENGR100A.desc: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the School of Engineering Honors Program. Graded CR/NC.

ENGR100B.name: ENGR 100b: Engineering Honors Colloquium (1.0 unit)
ENGR100B.desc: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the School of Engineering Honors Program. Graded CR/NC.

ENGR100C.name: ENGR 100c: Engineering Honors Colloquium (1.0 unit)
ENGR100C.desc: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the School of Engineering Honors Program. Graded CR/NC.

ENGR100D.name: ENGR 100d: Engineering Honors Colloquium (1.0 unit)
ENGR100D.desc: Recent developments in a highly technological society with emphasis on selected topics. Enrollment limited to members of the School of Engineering Honors Program. Graded CR/NC.

ENGR102.name: ENGR 102: Engineering Freshman Academy (2.0 units)
ENGR102.desc: Introduction to the profession of engineering. Ethical, political and societal consequences of engineering innovations and the impact of engineering on everyday life. Team projects and guest lectures. Open to freshmen only.

ENGR301.name: Crosslist ENGR 301: Technology Entrepreneurship (3.0 units)
ENGR301.desc: Starting and managing a technological business: developing a viable concept, market and financial planning, product development, organizing the venture, protecting intellectual property rights. (Duplicates credit in BAEP 310, BAEP 423, BAEP 450, BAEP 451)

ENGR345.name: ENGR 345: Principles and Practices of Global Innovation (3.0 units)
ENGR345.desc: Learner-centered, cross-cultural, technology-enabled approaches to principles and industrial practices leveraging cultural diversity to inspire innovations for competitive global markets. Requires an extended semester of 22 weeks, including 2-week overseas project in early summer.

ENGR395A.name: ENGR 395ax: Cooperative Education Work Experience (1.0-2.0 units, max 5)
ENGR395A.desc: Supervised work experience in a professional environment related to specific degree program, academic level, and career objective. Acceptance into Cooperative Education Program required. Graded IP or CR/NC. Degree credit by departmental approval.

ENGR395B.name: ENGR 395bx: Cooperative Education Work Experience (1.0-2.0 units, max 5)
ENGR395B.desc: Supervised work experience in a professional environment related to specific degree program, academic level, and career objective. Acceptance into Cooperative Education Program is required. Graded IP or CR/NC. Degree credit by departmental approval.

ENGR395C.name: ENGR 395cx: Cooperative Education Work Experience (1.0-2.0 units, max 5)
ENGR395C.desc: Supervised work experience in a professional environment related to specific degree program, academic level, and career objective. Acceptance into Cooperative Program is required. Graded IP or CR/NC. Degree credit by department approval.

ENGR395D.name: ENGR 395dx: Cooperative Education Work Experience (1.0-2.0 units, max 5)
ENGR395D.desc: Supervised work experience in a professional environment related to specific degree program, academic level, and career objective. Acceptance into Cooperative Education Program is required. Graded IP or CR/NC. Degree credit by departmental approval.

ENGR410.name: ENGR 410: Social Media for Scientists and Engineers (2.0 units)
ENGR410.desc: An introduction to the various ways in which social media and science are intersecting in a compelling manner; new technologies and online communities are powerful tools that are changing the ways in which scientists are engaging one another (inreach) and general audiences (outreach).

ENGR502.name: ENGR 502x: Writing Skills for Engineering Ph.D. Students (2.0 units, max 4)
ENGR502.desc: Writing of engineering curriculum- and research-related projects for Ph.D. students. Focus is on conference papers, dissertations and proposals, journal articles, and other forms. Graded CR/NC. Not available for credit to master's students.

ENGR503.name: ENGR 503x: Oral Communication Skills for Engineering Ph.D. Students (2.0 units, max 4)
ENGR503.desc: Academic and professional presentation skills for Ph.D. students. Preparation for qualifying exams, conference paper presentations, and other forms of oral communication. Use of visual aids and poster displays included. Graded CR/NC. Not available for degree credit to master's students.

ENGR596.name: ENGR 596: Internship in Engineering (1.0 units, max 3)
ENGR596.desc: Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. May not be taken until the student has completed at least one semester of enrollment in the graduate program. Graduate standing in engineering. Graded CR/NC.

ISE105.name: ISE 105: Introduction to Industrial and Systems Engineering (2.0 units)
ISE105.desc: A combination of plant tours, laboratory experiences, and lecture are used to introduce the philosophy, subject matter, aims, goals, and techniques of industrial and systems engineering.

ISE220.name: ISE 220: Probability Concepts in Engineering (3.0 units)
ISE220.desc: Techniques for handling uncertainties in engineering design: discrete and continuous random variables; expectations, probability distributions and transformations of random variables; limit theorems; approximations and applications. Prerequisite: MATH 126.

ISE315.name: ISE 315L: Engineering Project Management (3.0 units)
ISE315.desc: Techniques for planning, budgeting, scheduling, obtaining resources, monitoring and control of projects in a corporate environment. Use of software to evaluate performance and assess risks. Prerequisite: ISE 225 and ISE 330.

ISE327.name: ISE 327: Six Sigma and Lean Operations (3.0 units)
ISE327.desc: Standardized methodology for problem solving, basic and advanced statistical tools for root cause identification and solution confirmation, key principles for quality management and organizational excellence. Prerequisite: ISE 225.

ISE331.name: ISE 331: Introduction to Operations Research: Stochastic Models (3.0 units)
ISE331.desc: Stochastic processes; Markov chains; queueing theory and queueing decision models; probabilistic inventory models. Recommended preparation: ISE 330

ISE370.name: ISE 370L: Human Factors in Work Design (4.0 units)
ISE370.desc: Physiological systems and psychological characteristics; ergonomics; anthropometry; effects of the physical environment on humans; occupational safety and health; work methods.

ISE375.name: ISE 375L: Facilities Design (3.0 units)
ISE375.desc: Design of facilities for operations and distribution. Product, process flow, material handling, and facility location techniques that lead to making good decisions for facilities layouts.

ISE382.name: ISE 382: Database Systems: Concepts, Design and Implementation (4.0 units)
ISE382.desc: Data models for industry applications. Modeling and designing robust databases. Implementing and querying databases with SQL. Innovations in database applications.

ISE410.name: ISE 410: Planning and Scheduling (3.0 units)
ISE410.desc: Production planning, forecasting, scheduling, and inventory; computer integrated decision systems in analysis and control of production systems. Prerequisite: ISE 330.

ISE422.name: Crosslist ISE 422: Configuring Enterprise Resource Planning Systems (4.0 units)
ISE422.desc: Business process integration is the core advantage of using ERP systems. Analyze, configure, and test business processes for a company from the ground up.

ISE426.name: ISE 426: Statistical Quality Control (3.0 units)
ISE426.desc: Quantitative aspects of statistical quality control (process control, acceptance sampling by attribute and by variable, rectifying inspection), quality assurance and the management of QC/QA functions.

ISE435.name: ISE 435: Discrete Systems Simulation (3.0 units)
ISE435.desc: Model design to simulate discrete event systems with basic input and output analysis using high order languages, applied to industrial systems analysis and design problems. Prerequisites: CSCI 101 and ISE 225.

ISE440.name: ISE 440: Work, Technology, and Organization (3.0 units)
ISE440.desc: Impact of technology on work and organizational design; effects of automation; design of improvement programs; information infrastructures; teams; individual behavioral outcomes. Upper division standing.

ISE460.name: ISE 460: Engineering Economy (3.0 units)
ISE460.desc: Utilizing principles of economic analysis for choice of engineering alternatives and engineering systems. Pre-tax and after-tax economy studies. Upper division standing.

ISE487.name: Crosslist ISE 487: Enterprise Data Analytics (4.0 units)
ISE487.desc: Methodology to store, organize, cleanse, harmonize and stage enterprise data for analytics. Report, visualize, slice and dice, forecast and predict trends.

ISE488.name: Crosslist ISE 488: Managing Supply Chains with Advanced Planning & Optimization (3.0 units)
ISE488.desc: Drivers and obstacles to the process of coordinating the flow of material/information along the logistics chain. Optimize the supply network, from raw materials to sales. Not available for major credit in engineering except toward undergraduate and graduate programs offered by the Epstein Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering.

ISE495A.name: ISE 495ax: Senior Design Project (2.0 units)
ISE495A.desc: a: Preparation and development of the senior project proposal. Not available for graduate credit. Senior standing in industrial and systems engineering. Prerequisites: ISE 225 and ISE 460 and DSO 435 or ISE 382.

ISE495B.name: ISE 495bx: Senior Design Project (2.0 units)
ISE495B.desc: Group work on an industrial engineering design problem in an organization. Not available for graduate credit. Senior standing in industrial and systems engineering. Prerequisites: ISE 315 and ISE 435 and ISE 370 or ISE 470. Open only to Industrial and Systems Engineering majors.

ISE502.name: Crosslist ISE 502: Construction Business (4.0 units)
ISE502.desc: Fundamental accounting principles, financial analysis and financial control, strategic management, and a review of alternative project delivery methods.

ISE508.name: ISE 508: Health Care Operations Improvement (3.0 units)
ISE508.desc: Improving operations, patient flow, quality and processes. Students will become familiar with methods for implementing change in health care settings such as hospitals or clinics.

ISE511.name: ISE 511: Mechatronic Systems Engineering (3.0 units)
ISE511.desc: Use of mechanical, electrical, and computer engineering, math, and computer science to design of high performance and sophisticated products and processes and systems involving mechatronic.

ISE512.name: Crosslist ISE 512: Software Management and Economics (4.0 units)
ISE512.desc: Theories of management and their application to software projects. Economic analysis of software products and processes. Software cost and schedule estimation, planning and control.

ISE514.name: ISE 514: Advanced Production Planning and Scheduling (3.0 units)
ISE514.desc: Advanced concepts in production planning and scheduling including resource allocation, lot sizing, flow shop and job shop scheduling, workforce scheduling and assembly line balancing. Recommended preparation: prior knowledge of operations research and probability theory.

ISE515.name: ISE 515: Engineering Project Management (3.0 units)
ISE515.desc: Applying industrial and systems engineering skills to problems drawn from industry, while working in teams of 3-4 students. Teach project management skills and provide direct experience in managing and executing a group project.

ISE527.name: ISE 527: Quality Management for Engineers (3.0 units)
ISE527.desc: Principles of quality management, quality philosophies and frameworks, quality leadership and strategic planning, process management, and performance measurements.

ISE529.name: ISE 529: Predictive Analytics (3.0 units)
ISE529.desc: Analytics for supervised and unsupervised statistical learning. Generalized linear models, discriminant analysis, support vector machines. Nonparametric classification, trees, ensemble methods, k-nearest neighbors. Principal components, clustering.

ISE536.name: ISE 536: Linear Programming and Extensions (3.0 units)
ISE536.desc: Linear programming models for resource allocation; simplex and revised simplex methods; duality; sensitivity; transportation problems; selected extensions to large scale, multiobjective, and special structured models.

ISE538.name: ISE 538: Performance Analysis Using Markov Models (3.0 units)
ISE538.desc: Random variables, stochastic processes, birth and death processes, continuous- and discrete-time Markov chains with finite and infinite number of states, renewal phenomena and queuing systems.

ISE544.name: ISE 544: Management of Engineering Teams (3.0 units)
ISE544.desc: Design and management of engineering teams. Group decision-making, motivation, leadership, infrastructure requirements, performance measurement, team diversity, conflict, and integration.

ISE545.name: ISE 545: Technology Development and Implementation (3.0 units)
ISE545.desc: Principles and practices of technology development and implementation, with application to products and systems in manufacturing and services.

ISE556.name: Crosslist ISE 556: Stochastic Systems and Reinforcement Learning (4.0 units)
ISE556.desc: Stochastic system models, Dynamic programming, Linear quadratic control, Kalman filtering and estimation, System identification, approximate dynamic programming methods, adaptive control, reinforcement and online learning.

ISE560.name: Crosslist ISE 560: Analysis of Algorithms (4.0 units)
ISE560.desc: Explores fundamental techniques such as recursion, Fourier transform ordering, dynamic programming for efficient algorithm construction. Examples include arithmetic, algebraic, graph, pattern matching, sorting, searching algorithms.

ISE561.name: ISE 561: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects (3.0 units)
ISE561.desc: Economic evaluations of engineering systems for both government and private industry; quantitative techniques for evaluating non-monetary consequences; formal treatment of risk and uncertainty. Prerequisite: ISE 500. Recommended preparation: An undergraduate course in engineering economy.

ISE562.name: ISE 562: Decision Analysis (3.0 units)
ISE562.desc: Decision making under risk conditions; utility theory; sufficient statistics; conjugate prior distributions; terminal and pre-posterior analysis; Bayesian statistics versus classical statistics.

ISE563.name: ISE 563: Financial Engineering (3.0 units)
ISE563.desc: Concepts underlying the economic analysis of engineering projects; applications to call and put options; utility theory and mathematical optimizations models; and simulation. Recommended preparation ISE 220 or an equivalent course in probability.

ISE568.name: Crosslist ISE 568: Machine Learning (4.0 units)
ISE568.desc: Statistical methods for building intelligent and adaptive systems that improve performance from experiences; Focus on theoretical understanding of these methods and their computational implications. Recommended preparation: Undergraduate level training or coursework in linear algebra, multivariate calculus, basic probability and statistics; an undergraduate level course in Artificial Intelligence may be helpful but is not required.

ISE585.name: ISE 585: Strategic Management of Technology (3.0 units)
ISE585.desc: Management skills and tools for technology intensive enterprises. Life cycle analysis of technology from planning through exploitation, obsolescence and renewal.

ISE599.name: ISE 599: Special Topics (2.0-4.0 units, max 9)
ISE599.desc: Course content will be selected each semester to reflect current trends and developments in the field of industrial and systems engineering.

ISE610.name: ISE 610: Advance Design of Experiments and Quality Engineering . . (3.0 units)
ISE610.desc: Advanced planning for data collection in order to investigate relationships between product/process design choices and performance; empirical modeling to predict performance; identification of the best design.

ISE631.name: ISE 631: Linear Programming (3.0 units)
ISE631.desc: Doctoral course in optimization, the foundation for subsequent courses in mathematical programming. For first-year Ph.D. students and M.S. students who intend to pursue a Ph.D. Recommended preparation: One year of calculus and one semester of linear and matrix algebra.

ISE633.name: ISE 633: Large Scale Optimization and Machine Learning (3.0 units)
ISE633.desc: Large scale optimization algorithms that arise in modern data science and machine learning applications. Stochastic Optimization, Accelerated Methods, Parallelization, Online Optimization, Randomized Linear Algebra

ISE651.name: ISE 651: Seminar in Industrial & Systems Engineering (1.0 units, max 4)
ISE651.desc: Current research, guest speakers in the field; review papers; guidance in preparing research proposals and special projects. Duplicates credit in the former ISE-650abc. Open only to Fifth Year Seniors and Masterâ€™s Students.

ISE670.name: Crosslist ISE 670: Advanced Analysis of Algorithms (4.0 units)
ISE670.desc: Fundamental techniques for design and analysis of algorithms. Dynamic programming; network flows; theory of NP-completeness; linear programming; approximation, randomized, and online algorithms; basic cryptography. Prerequisite: CSCI 570. Recommended preparation: familiarity with algorithms and discrete mathematics. Open only to doctoral students.

INF250.name: INF 250: Introduction to Data Informatics (4.0 units)
INF250.desc: Fundamentals of data informatics: representation of data and knowledge, role of a data scientist, data storage/processing/analytics, machine learning, big data, and data visualization. Recommended preparation: A basic understanding of engineering and/or technology is recommended.

INF429.name: INF 429: Security and Privacy (4.0 units)
